instruction: When should I use .test page to prevent text from splitting across pages?
output: Use .test page when you have a block of text that should not be split across page boundaries. Specify the number of lines your text block requires. If there are enough lines remaining on the current page, the text will be output there. If there aren't enough lines remaining, a page break will be forced and the text will start on the next page. This is particularly useful for keeping related content like tables, code blocks, or multi-line examples together on a single page.

instruction: How does .test page determine whether to stay on the current page or move to the next?
input: Parameter: number.lines - If the number of lines specified is less than the count returned, the text following is output on the current page. Otherwise, a page is ejected and the text is output on the new page. This prevents blocks of text from being split across a page boundary.
output: The .test page command compares the number of lines you specify with the number of lines remaining on the current page. If the number of lines you specify is less than or equal to the lines remaining on the page, the following text is output on the current page. If the number of lines you specify is greater than the lines remaining, a page break is issued and the text is output on the new page instead.

instruction: Give me an example of using .test page to keep 10 lines together.
input:
Example: Tests to determine if there are at least 10 print lines remaining on the current output page. If there are, the text following is printed on the same page, otherwise, a form feed is issued and the text prints on the next page.
.test page 10
output:
Here's how to use .test page to keep 10 lines together:

```
.test page 10
```

This command tests whether there are at least 10 print lines remaining on the current output page. If there are 10 or more lines available, the text following this command will be printed on the same page. If there are fewer than 10 lines remaining, a form feed (page break) is issued and the text prints on the next page, ensuring your 10-line block stays together.

instruction: How do I underline text until I want to stop the underlining?
input:

D3
output: Use the .underline command to start underlining text. The underlining will continue for all following text (including spaces) until you encounter either an .xul or .x command to stop it. The underlining works on printers and terminals that support the underline function. For example, `.underline D3 .xul` will underline the text 'D3' and then stop underlining.

instruction: Does .underline affect spaces between words as well as the words themselves?
input: Description: The .underline command underlines the text following until an .xul or .x command is encountered. This command underlines spaces as well a words, and works on printers and terminals that support the underline function.

instruction: What commands can I use to stop underlining that was started with .underline?
input: Description: The .underline command underlines the text following until an .xul or .x command is encountered.

instruction: How can I force text to display in uppercase letters?

instruction: How do I control the vertical spacing between lines in my output?
input:
Syntax: .vmi number.lines

Description: The .vmi command specifies the amount of vertical space each line uses. The .vmi spacing is allocated in 2.08-inch increments, and is essentially the flip side of the .lpi command. For example, if the .lpi is set to 6, the equivalent .vmi setting is 8.

Parameter: number.lines - Specifies the number of lines per inch. The default is 8.
output: Use the .vmi command to control vertical spacing between lines. The syntax is `.vmi number.lines` where number.lines specifies the lines per inch. The .vmi command is essentially the inverse of the .lpi command - if .lpi is set to 6 lines per inch, the equivalent .vmi setting would be 8. The default setting is 8 lines per inch. The spacing is allocated in increments of 1/48th of an inch (2.08-inch increments).

instruction: What's the relationship between .vmi and .lpi commands?
input: Description: The .vmi command specifies the amount of vertical space each line uses. The .vmi spacing is allocated in 2.08-inch increments, and is essentially the flip side of the .lpi command. For example, if the .lpi is set to 6, the equivalent .vmi setting is 8.
output: The .vmi and .lpi commands are inverse relationships for controlling vertical spacing. The .vmi command specifies vertical motion (space between lines) while .lpi specifies lines per inch. They are essentially flip sides of each other - when .lpi is set to 6 lines per inch, the equivalent .vmi setting is 8. These commands work together to control the same aspect of document formatting from different perspectives.

instruction: Will .vmi work if my printer doesn't support vertical motion?
input: CAUTION: If the printer does not support vertical motion, this command has no affect.
output: No, the .vmi command will have no effect if your printer does not support vertical motion. The command depends on the printer's ability to control vertical spacing, so it's important to verify that your output device supports this functionality before relying on .vmi for formatting.

instruction: Show me how to set line spacing to approximately four lines per inch.

To set line spacing to approximately four lines per inch, use:


This sets the vertical motion to 12, which results in approximately four lines per inch with an actual line spacing of .25-inch per line.

instruction: How do linkages work for transferring control between Procs?
input:
Description: Linkages are the means by which Procs either pass control one way to another Proc, or call another Proc as an external subroutine. The type of linkage is determined by the character used in the syntax.

Brackets can be used as an internal subroutine call when both the file name and item-ID are omitted, and a statement label is included. The internal subroutine returns to the next line after the call when it encounters an x command.
output: Linkages in Procs are used to transfer control between different Procs or call them as subroutines. The type of linkage is determined by the character used in the syntax - parentheses for one-way transfers or external subroutine calls, and brackets for internal subroutine calls. When using brackets with just a statement label (omitting file name and item-ID), you create an internal subroutine call that returns to the next line after the call when it encounters an x command.

instruction: What's the difference between using parentheses and brackets in Proc linkages?
output: The difference between parentheses and brackets in Proc linkages determines the type of control transfer. Parentheses () are used for one-way control transfers or external subroutine calls, while brackets [] are used for subroutine calls that return control to the calling Proc. The specific behavior depends on whether you include file names, item-IDs, and labels in the syntax.

instruction: Can you show me examples of different types of Proc linkages?
input:
Examples: Transfers control to example1 in the procs file. Control returns to the next line in the current Proc upon completion.
[procs example1]

Transfers control to example2 in the procs file, and begins execution at statement label 25. Control returns to the next line in the current Proc upon completion.
[procs example2] 25

Transfers control to statement label 150 in the current Proc and begins execution.
[] 150

Transfers control to the procs file, using the item-ID indicated in the input buffer.
(procs)
output:
Here are examples of different Proc linkage types:

1. External subroutine call: `[procs example1]` - calls example1 in the procs file and returns
2. External subroutine with label: `[procs example2] 25` - calls example2 starting at label 25 and returns
3. Internal subroutine: `[] 150` - jumps to label 150 in the current Proc
4. Dynamic transfer: `(procs)` - transfers to procs file using the item-ID from the input buffer

Brackets [] return control after completion, while parentheses () typically indicate one-way transfers or dynamic calls.

instruction: How do I move text from the input buffer to the output buffer in a Proc?
input:
Syntax: a{surround.char}{param.num, num.chars|(start.pos, num.chars)}

Description: The a command appends the string in the specified input buffer position to the currently active output buffer. Multiple parameters may be moved to the currently active output buffer using a single a command if these parameters are separated by semicolons in the input buffer.
output: Use the a command to append text from the input buffer to the currently active output buffer. The syntax is `a{surround.char}{param.num, num.chars|(start.pos, num.chars)}`. You can specify a parameter number, the number of characters to move, or a starting position and character count. You can also specify a surround character to enclose the moved text. Multiple parameters separated by semicolons can be moved with a single a command.

instruction: What does the surround character do in the a command?
input: Parameter: surround.char - Specifies the character to place before and after the string after it is moved. Can be any nonnumeric character except the left parenthesis. If a backslash is specified, the parameter is moved without any surrounding spaces.
output: The surround character in the a command specifies a character to place before and after the string when it's moved to the output buffer. It can be any nonnumeric character except the left parenthesis. If you specify a backslash (\), the parameter is moved without any surrounding spaces, which is useful for picking up item-IDs and values that require double quotes for AQL processor processing. Note that specifying a surround character has no effect when moving parameters to the secondary output buffer.

instruction: Show me examples of different ways to use the a command.
input:
Examples: Appends the contents of input buffer one to the currently active output buffer, string will be surrounded by double quotation marks.
a"1

Appends the second through 999th (or whenever it runs out of characters) to the currently active output buffer.
a(2,999)

Appends the contents of parameter 2 to the currently active output buffer.
s2
a
output:
Here are different ways to use the a command:

1. With surround character: `a"1` - appends parameter 1 surrounded by double quotes
2. With position and length: `a(2,999)` - appends from position 2 through position 999 (or end of data)
3. With pointer positioning: `s2` followed by `a` - first positions to parameter 2, then appends it

Each method allows you to control exactly what text is moved and how it's formatted in the output buffer.

instruction: How do I add comments to my Proc code?
input:
Syntax: c {text}

Description: The c command indicates a remark command. All text that follows on the same line is ignored by the PROC interpreter. Use this command to insert text that adds clarity and readability to a Proc. Keep in mind that since a Proc is an interpreted command, excessive comments slow down execution.
output: Use the c command to add comments to your Proc code. The syntax is `c {text}` where everything following the c on the same line is treated as a comment and ignored by the PROC interpreter. Comments help add clarity and readability to your Proc, but keep in mind that since Procs are interpreted, excessive comments can slow down execution.

instruction: Will comments in my Proc affect its execution speed?
input: Description: Use this command to insert text that adds clarity and readability to a Proc. Keep in mind that since a Proc is an interpreted command, excessive comments slow down execution.
output: Yes, comments can affect your Proc's execution speed. Since Procs are interpreted commands, excessive comments will slow down execution. While comments are valuable for clarity and readability, you should use them judiciously to balance code documentation with performance.

instruction: Give me an example of using the c command for comments.
input:
Example: pq
c This Proc runs the month-end processing
output:
Here's an example of using the c command for comments:

```
pq
c This Proc runs the month-end processing
```

The first line `pq` is a Proc command, and the second line starting with `c` is a comment explaining what the Proc does. The PROC interpreter will ignore everything after the `c` on that line.

instruction: How can I display specific parts of the input buffer during Proc execution?
output: Use the d command to display parts of the input buffer during Proc execution. You can specify a parameter number to display a specific position, use 0 to display all positions, or omit the parameter to display the current buffer pointer position. You can also specify the number of characters or a starting position and character count. Adding a + at the end suppresses the carriage return at the end of the display line.

instruction: What happens when I use d0 in a Proc?
input: Parameter: param.num - If zero is specified, then all positions in the buffer display.
output: When you use d0 in a Proc, it displays all positions in the currently active input buffer. This is useful for debugging or viewing the entire contents of the input buffer at once.

instruction: Can you show me what the d command displays for different buffer contents?
input:
Example: Active Input Buffer: list company assets
Command: d2, Data Displayed: company
Command: d0, Data Displayed: list company assets
Command: d3,4, Data Displayed: asse
Command: d3,4+, Data Displayed: asse
output:
Here's what the d command displays for the input buffer containing 'list company assets':

- `d2` displays: company (parameter 2)
- `d0` displays: list company assets (all parameters)
- `d3,4` displays: asse (4 characters from parameter 3)
- `d3,4+` displays: asse (same as above but without carriage return)

The + modifier suppresses the carriage return at the end of the display line.

instruction: How do I transfer control to a specific statement label in a Proc?
input:
Syntax: go statement.label|aparam.num

Description: The go command transfers program control to another Proc statement which starts with a statement label. If the statement label is not unique, the go command goes to the first occurrence of the statement label as it scans from the top. If the label does not exist, the go command is not executed.
output: Use the go command to transfer control to a specific statement label in a Proc. The syntax is `go statement.label` where statement.label is a numeric label. The command will jump to the first occurrence of that label when scanning from the top of the Proc. If the label doesn't exist, the go command is ignored. You can also use `go aparam.num` for indirect transfers based on a value stored in the input buffer.

instruction: What happens if I use go with a label that appears multiple times?
input: Description: If the statement label is not unique, the go command goes to the first occurrence of the statement label as it scans from the top.
output: If you use go with a label that appears multiple times in the Proc, the go command will transfer control to the first occurrence of that statement label as it scans from the top of the Proc. Subsequent occurrences of the same label will be ignored.

instruction: Show me examples of direct and indirect go commands.
input:
Examples: Transfers control to the Proc statement with label 99.
go 99

Transfers control to the Proc label that matches the value in the fourth position of the currently active input buffer.
go a4
output:
Here are examples of direct and indirect go commands:

1. Direct transfer: `go 99` - transfers control directly to statement label 99
2. Indirect transfer: `go a4` - transfers control to the label whose value is stored in the fourth position of the currently active input buffer

The indirect form allows dynamic branching based on data in the input buffer.

instruction: How do I add literal text to the output buffer in a Proc?
input:
Syntax: h{string}{<}

Description: The h command moves a literal string of characters to the currently active output buffer. Several h commands can be used to build suitable text. It does not actually output until a carriage return is placed into the buffer.
output: Use the h command to add literal text to the output buffer. The syntax is `h{string}` where string is the literal text you want to add. You can use multiple h commands to build up text in the output buffer. The text doesn't actually output until a carriage return is placed into the buffer. You can add `<` to place a carriage return in the output buffer, which is required when moving multiple parameters to the secondary output buffer.

instruction: When does text added with h commands actually get output?
input: Description: Several h commands can be used to build suitable text. It does not actually output until a carriage return is placed into the buffer.
output: Text added with h commands doesn't actually get output until a carriage return is placed into the output buffer. You can use multiple h commands to build up text, but the output won't be displayed until the buffer receives a carriage return command.

instruction: Show me how to use h commands to build output text.
input:
Examples: The h commands move the strings following them to the end of the currently active output buffer.
hlist entity
h name address phone
p

The < characters in the example are required to separate or stack the strings to execute after the list is retrieved.
hget-list invoices
ston
hlist-label invoices cust.name cust.addr custcsz (cip<
h1,3,1,0,30,0,c
p
output:
Here are examples of using h commands to build output text:

Simple example:
```
hlist entity
h name address phone
p
```
This builds the text 'list entity name address phone' and outputs it with the p command.

Complex example with secondary buffer:
```
hget-list invoices
ston
hlist-label invoices cust.name cust.addr custcsz (cip<
h1,3,1,0,30,0,c
p
```
This builds more complex output using the secondary buffer (ston) with the `<` character used to separate/stack strings for execution after list retrieval.

instruction: How do I create conditional logic in a Proc using the if command?
input:
Syntax: if {#} e {operator message.num} command
if {#} s command
if {#} a{param.num}{,n} {operator{'string'|(pattern.match)}} command

Description: The if command performs a conditional expression. Comparisons are performed one character at a time from left to right. For the purposes of comparison, letters are converted to uppercaseâ€”so uppercase and lowercase letters are equal.
output: Use the if command to create conditional logic in Procs. There are three main forms: `if e` for testing error conditions, `if s` for testing system conditions, and `if a` for testing input buffer parameters. You can use the `#` operator to reverse the condition (not equal). Comparisons are case-insensitive and performed character by character from left to right. Available operators include = (equal), # (not equal), < (less than), > (greater than), [ (less than or equal), and ] (greater than or equal).

instruction: What comparison operators are available for if commands?
input: Parameter: operator - The relational operators available are: = Equal to, # Not equal to, < Less than, > Greater than, [ Less than or equal to, ] Greater than or equal to
output:
The relational operators available for if commands are:
- = (Equal to)
- # (Not equal to) 
- < (Less than)
- > (Greater than)
- [ (Less than or equal to)
- ] (Greater than or equal to)

These operators can be used to compare values in conditional expressions within your Proc logic.

instruction: Can you show me examples of different if command patterns?
input:
Examples: Checks for error message 401 and stops/returns if present.
if e = 401 xno items were selected...

Checks for 3 numbers, a dash, 2 numbers, a dash, and 4 more numbers.
if a # (3n'-'2n'-'4n) oinvalid ss#.

Checks the currently active input buffer location for the presence of the letter x.
if a = x xdone.

Checks the first character of the currently active input buffer location for the presence of 0 or more numbers.
if a1,1 = q x proc terminated voluntarily
output:
Here are examples of different if command patterns:

1. Error checking: `if e = 401 xno items were selected...` - checks for specific error 401
2. Pattern matching: `if a # (3n'-'2n'-'4n) oinvalid ss#.` - validates Social Security number format
3. Simple value check: `if a = x xdone.` - checks if current buffer position contains 'x'
4. Character position check: `if a1,1 = q x proc terminated voluntarily` - checks if first character is 'q'

These examples show error testing, pattern validation, value comparison, and positional character checking.

instruction: How do I replace or modify data in the input buffer during Proc execution?
input:
Syntax: ih\
ih \
ih string

Description: The ih command removes the current parameter from the currently active input buffer and replaces it with a null value or the specified string.

Parameter: \ - Inserts a new null parameter in the current position of the currently active input buffer. string - Inputs the specified string, including all leading and trailing spaces, into the active input buffer at the current pointer position.
output: Use the ih command to replace or modify data in the input buffer. You can use `ih\` to replace the current parameter with a null value, or `ih string` to replace it with a specific string. If the pointer is in the middle of a position, the position is truncated starting at the current position and a new parameter is added after the truncation. The replacement string includes all leading and trailing spaces.

instruction: How would I output literal text to the terminal in a PROC processor?
input:
Syntax: o {text}{+}

The o command outputs literal text to the terminal at the next available line.

Parameter(s):
text - Text to output to the terminal including all leading and trailing spaces.
+ - Suppresses the usual carriage return at the end of the text.
output: Use the o command followed by the text you want to output. The syntax is 'o {text}{+}' where 'text' is the literal text to display and the optional '+' suppresses the carriage return at the end.

instruction: What does the + parameter do when using the o command?
input:
Syntax: o {text}{+}

The o command outputs literal text to the terminal at the next available line.

Parameter(s):
text - Text to output to the terminal including all leading and trailing spaces.
+ - Suppresses the usual carriage return at the end of the text.
output: The + parameter suppresses the usual carriage return at the end of the text when using the o command. This allows you to continue output on the same line.

instruction: Can you show me an example of using the o command in PROC?
input:
Example(s):
o
o This reports takes a while to run...
o Please sit by...
o
output:
Here's an example of using the o command:

o
o This reports takes a while to run...
o Please sit by...
o

This outputs blank lines and text messages to inform the user about a running process.

instruction: Explain how the p command processes output buffers in PROC
input:
The p command processes the commands in the currently active output buffers. The primary output buffer is processed first, followed by the secondary output buffer. Both the primary and secondary output buffers are automatically reset after the p command, and the active buffer pointer is reset to point to the primary output buffer.

The p command submits the contents of the primary output buffer to TCL for processing. The contents of the secondary output buffer are used as input for other interactive processors.
output: The p command processes commands in the active output buffers in sequence - first the primary output buffer, then the secondary output buffer. It submits the primary buffer contents to TCL for processing, while the secondary buffer contents are used as input for other interactive processors. After execution, both buffers are automatically reset and the active buffer pointer returns to the primary output buffer.

instruction: What are the different options available with the p command?
input:
Parameter(s):
option - Type of additional options to perform:
h - Suppress output to the terminal.
p - Display the contents of both output buffers.
w - Display the contents of both output buffers, then wait for response from the terminal. Valid responses are:
g or pressing ENTER - Proceeds with the process.
s - Skip to the next command in the Proc.
x or n - Abort the Proc.
x - After the TCL command has been processed, abort the rest of the Proc, if any, and return to TCL.
output:
The p command supports several options:
- h: Suppress output to the terminal
- p: Display the contents of both output buffers
- w: Display buffer contents and wait for user response (g/ENTER to proceed, s to skip, x/n to abort)
- x: Process the TCL command then abort the remaining Proc and return to TCL

instruction: Show me a practical example of the p command with both buffers
input:
Example(s):
hselect entity by name
ston
hsave-list entity.by.name
p

The p command in this example processes the commands in both output buffers.
output:
Here's an example using both buffers:

hselect entity by name
ston
hsave-list entity.by.name
p

In this example, the p command processes the AQL commands 'hselect entity by name' and 'hsave-list entity.by.name' from both the primary and secondary output buffers.

instruction: How do I reset input buffers in PROC using the ri command?
input:
Syntax: ri{start.parameter}

The ri command resets either the entire Proc input buffer, or all of the locations following a specified location, and resets both input buffers to null.

Parameter(s):
start.parameter - Indicates the starting position to reset. All parameters following the specified parameter and the entire secondary input buffer are cleared.
output: Use the ri command to reset input buffers. Without parameters, 'ri' clears both input buffers completely. With a start parameter, 'ri{start.parameter}' clears all parameters following the specified position and the entire secondary input buffer.

instruction: What's the difference between using ri with and without parameters?
input:
Example(s):
Clears both input buffers.
ri

Clears only the secondary input buffer.
ss
ri
sp
output: Using 'ri' without parameters clears both input buffers completely. However, when used with switching commands like 'ss' (switch to secondary) followed by 'ri' and 'sp' (switch to primary), it clears only the secondary input buffer while leaving the primary buffer intact.

instruction: How would I set the input pointer to a specific position in PROC?
input:
Syntax: s{parameter.number}

The s command sets the input pointer to a specified position number, activating the specified parameter number as the currently active input buffer location.

Parameter(s):
parameter.number - Specifies the position number.
output: Use the s command followed by the parameter number to set the input pointer. For example, 's1' sets the input pointer to position 1, making parameter 1 the currently active input buffer location.

instruction: When should I use the st command to control output buffer direction?
input:
Syntax: st [on|off]

The st command selects and directs output either to the primary output buffer (turns off the stack) or to the secondary output buffer (turns on the stack). When the stack is off, all data picked up by the a command is put in the primary output buffer. When the stack is on, the data is put in the secondary output buffer.
output: Use the st command to control which output buffer receives data from the a command. Use 'st off' to direct output to the primary buffer (default), or 'st on' to direct output to the secondary buffer. This is useful when you need to separate different types of commands or data for processing.

instruction: Can you demonstrate the st command with an example?
input:
Example(s):
hsselect entity by name
st on
hsave-list entity.list
p
output:
Here's an example of the st command:

hsselect entity by name
st on
hsave-list entity.list
p

This example first executes 'hsselect entity by name', then turns on the stack with 'st on' to direct the 'hsave-list entity.list' command to the secondary output buffer before processing with 'p'.

instruction: What terminal display functions can I control with the t command?
input:
Syntax: t {function, function,...}

The t command directs output to the terminal screen and controls special terminal display functions.

Parameter(s):
function - b: Brings the terminal bell, c: Clears the terminal screen, (column,row): Outputs the value at the column and row coordinates, in: Outputs ASCII character with an integer value of n, xn: Outputs ASCII character with integer hexadecimal value of n, "text": Outputs literal text
output: The t command provides various terminal control functions including: 'b' for terminal bell, 'c' for clearing screen, '(column,row)' for cursor positioning, 'in' for ASCII characters by integer value, 'xn' for ASCII characters by hex value, and '"text"' for literal text output. You can combine multiple functions in one command.

instruction: How do I position the cursor and display text using the t command?
input:
Example(s):
Clears the screen, (-1) positions the cursor at column 20, row 0, and displays the string Main Menu.
t (-1),(20,0),"Main Menu"

Positions the cursor to column 10, row 10, displays the string "Chosen" in reverse video, (-13) and (-14), and clears to the end of the line (-4).
t (10,10),(-13),"Chosen",(-14),(-4)
output:
To position the cursor and display text, use coordinates and text in the t command. For example:
't (-1),(20,0),"Main Menu"' clears the screen, positions cursor at column 20 row 0, and displays "Main Menu".
't (10,10),(-13),"Chosen",(-14),(-4)' positions cursor at column 10 row 10, displays "Chosen" in reverse video, then clears to end of line.

instruction: Explain how the u01a2 user exit performs computed goto branching
input:
Syntax:
u01a2
index arg1... argn
(jump here if index = arg1)
:
(jump here if index = argn)
(continue here if no arguments match)

User exit u01a2 executes a computed goto branch based on the value in the current output buffer.

Parameter(s):
index - Value to compare against one or more arguments.
arg1...argn - Values to compare against the index. If a match is made, control passes to the n+1 line below the user exit call.
output: The u01a2 user exit performs computed goto branching by comparing an index value against a list of arguments. If the index matches arg1, control jumps to the first line after the user exit call; if it matches arg2, control jumps to the second line, and so on. If no match is found, execution continues sequentially after all the jump targets.

instruction: Show me a working example of the u01a2 computed goto
input:
Example(s):
001 pq
002 o Demonstration of the computed-goto
003 o Enter: YES, NO, or MAYBE
004 st on
005 h1
006 in
007 a
008 h3
009 u01a2
010 2 YES NO MAYBE
011 g 100
012 g 200
013 g 300
014 x Sorry, only a YES, NO, or MAYBE may be entered.
015
100 x You entered a YES
016
200 x You entered a NO
017
300 x You entered a MAYBE
output:
Here's a complete example of u01a2:

Lines 001-008 get user input, then u01a2 at line 009 compares the input against "YES", "NO", "MAYBE". If input is "YES", it jumps to line 100; if "NO", to line 200; if "MAYBE", to line 300. If none match, it continues to line 014 with an error message. Each target line (100, 200, 300) displays the appropriate response.

instruction: What's the purpose of the u01a6 user exit and why should I avoid it?
input:
Syntax: u01a6
control.code{,control.code,}...

User exit u01a6 performs cursor control functions. Nearly all the functionality of this user exit is available through the t PROC command, which should be preferred to this user exit.
output: The u01a6 user exit performs cursor control functions like positioning cursors, clearing screens, and outputting characters. However, you should avoid using u01a6 because nearly all its functionality is available through the t PROC command, which is the preferred method for terminal control operations.

instruction: How do I retrieve values from file attributes using the u01ad user exit?
input:
Syntax:
u01ad
file.name item-ID attribute.ref code.number

User exit u01ad retrieves a value from an attribute of an item in a file. The next line of the Proc specifies the file information.

Parameter(s):
file.name - Name of the file. If the file name is prefixed with an asterisk, the dictionary portion of the file is accessed.
item-ID - Item name.
attribute.ref - Attribute name (or number).
code.number - a: Outputs to the alternative output buffer, p: Outputs to the primary input buffer, s: Outputs to the current output buffer, t: Outputs to the terminal, v: Verifies that the file exists, va: Verifies that the attribute exists.
output: The u01ad user exit retrieves values from file attributes by specifying the file name, item ID, attribute reference, and a code number that determines the output destination. Use codes like 's' for current output buffer, 't' for terminal, 'v' to verify file existence, or 'va' to verify attribute existence. You can also use indirect references with % symbols.

instruction: Can you show both direct and indirect reference examples for u01ad?
input:
Example(s):
Direct Reference
pq
u01ad control-file co.name 1 s
xcan't find co.name or control.file
Reads attribute 1 of the item called co.name in the file named control-file and places it in the current output buffer.

Indirect Reference
pq
u01ad %2 %3 %4 p
xsomething went wrong...
d0
Reads the attribute number as defined in the fourth location of the input buffer, using the item-ID from the third location and the file name from the second location.
output:
Direct reference example:
u01ad control-file co.name 1 s
This reads attribute 1 from item 'co.name' in 'control-file' and outputs to current buffer.

Indirect reference example:
u01ad %2 %3 %4 p
This uses values from input buffer positions 2 (file name), 3 (item ID), and 4 (attribute number) and outputs to primary input buffer.

instruction: How does the u11a2 user exit format numbers with leading zeros?
input:
Syntax:
u11a2
number.of.digits

User exit u11a2 pads the current input buffer with enough leading zeros to make the value in the number of digits a specific number of digits wide, and returns the resulting string to the secondary input buffer.

Parameter(s):
number.of.digits - Sets the width of the number of digits.
output: The u11a2 user exit pads numbers with leading zeros to achieve a specified width. It takes the value from the current input buffer, adds leading zeros as needed to reach the specified number of digits, and returns the formatted result to the secondary input buffer. For example, with width 4, the values 1, 01, 001, or 0001 would all become 0001.

instruction: What happens when I use the u91a2 user exit to transfer control?
input:
Syntax:
proc
u91a2

User exit u91a2 transfers control to the specified Proc name in the primary output buffer. The primary input buffer is unaffected. Both output buffers are cleared.

Example(s):
001 pq
002 st off
003 hnew.proc
004 u91a2
output: The u91a2 user exit transfers control to another Proc whose name is specified in the primary output buffer. When executed, it leaves the primary input buffer unchanged but clears both output buffers. In the example, it loads 'new.proc' into the output buffer with 'hnew.proc' then transfers control to that Proc with u91a2.

instruction: How does the b processing code maintain relationships between files?
input:
Syntax: bfile.reference;attr1;attr2{;{attr3;+|-}|d}

The b processing code maintains a horizontal relationship (bridge) between an attribute in one item and an item in another file (or the same file) on the system level. When an item is added, changed, or deleted, all the bridge correlatives in the file-defining item of the file dictionary are processed for that item.

Parameter(s):
file.reference - Refers to the file in which the bridge is being built.
attr1 - Contains the attribute in the current item that contains the item-ID of the item in the bridged-to file.
attr2 - Contains the attribute in the bridged-to item that is referenced by the bridge.
output: The b processing code creates and maintains horizontal relationships (bridges) between files by automatically updating related items when data changes. It uses attr1 from the current item as an item-ID pointer to the bridged file, and updates attr2 in the target item. This happens automatically during add, change, or delete operations, eliminating the need for manual FlashBASIC coding to maintain cross-references.

instruction: What's the difference between the arithmetic and delete options in bridge processing?
input:
Parameter(s):
attr3;+|- - Adds or subtracts the value of the attribute specified by attribute count 3 in the current item to the value in the attribute count 2 in the bridged-to item. The inverse operation is performed on a delete.
d - Used as an override to delete the current item even if attribute count 1 is not null. Without this option, the current item may not be deleted if the attribute specified by attribute count 1 contains a value.
output: The arithmetic options (+/-) perform mathematical operations between items: '+' adds the value from attr3 in the current item to attr2 in the bridged item, while '-' subtracts it. On delete, the inverse operation is performed. The 'd' option is a delete override that allows deletion of the current item even when attr1 contains a value, which would normally prevent deletion to maintain referential integrity.

instruction: How do I concatenate multiple elements using the c processing code?
output: The c processing code concatenates multiple elements for output. You can combine numeric constants, attribute positions (referenced by number), and quoted text strings. Use semicolons to separate elements without displaying separators, or specify custom separators with 'x' followed by the separator character. The asterisk (*) concatenates results from the previous processing code operation.

instruction: Can you show me examples of different concatenation formats?
input:
Example(s):
Stored Value | Processing Code | Output Data
014 'Hunter' | c"Name :";14,15 | 'Name: Hunter,Rockwell'
015 'Rockwell' |
001 'day' | c1/2 | 'day/night'
002 'night' |
output:
Here are concatenation examples:

1. c"Name :";14,15 - Combines the literal text "Name :" with values from attributes 14 and 15, producing 'Name: Hunter,Rockwell'

2. c1/2 - Concatenates attribute 1 and attribute 2 with a '/' separator, producing 'day/night' from stored values 'day' and 'night'

instruction: What's the difference between controlling and dependent processing codes?
input:
Syntax: c;ac{;ac...}

The c processing code defines the controlling attribute in a controlling/dependent pair of attributes when placed in attribute 4 of the ADI. A controlling/dependent set of attributes is two or more attributes that are associated. In an AQL report, to see dependent attributes, controlling attributes must be specified.
output: The c processing code (when used as a controlling code) defines master attributes that control the display of associated dependent attributes. Controlling attributes must be specified in AQL reports and Update processor to show their dependent attributes. The dependent attributes use the 'd' code to reference their controlling attribute, creating linked attribute relationships.

instruction: How would I set up a controlling/dependent attribute relationship?
input:
Example(s):
In this example, order# is the controlling attribute and controls the values in attributes 4, 5, and 6. Each of these three controlled attributes must indicate in their corresponding attribute-defining items that they are dependent upon attribute 3.

id: order# quantity price ext.price
001 a a a a
002 3 4 5 6
003
004 c;4;5;6 d;3 d;3 d;3
output:
To set up controlling/dependent relationships:
1. In the controlling attribute (order#), use 'c;4;5;6' in attribute 4 to specify which attributes it controls
2. In each dependent attribute (quantity, price, ext.price), use 'd;3' in attribute 4 to indicate they depend on attribute 3 (order#)
3. This creates a relationship where displaying dependent attributes requires the controlling attribute to be specified.

instruction: When should I use the call processing code to invoke subroutines?
input:
Syntax: call {file.spec} module

The call processing code calls a BASIC or FlashBASIC subroutine from the file-defining item or an ADI. Called subroutines are Flash compiled to improve performance. Subroutines can be called from the correlative or input-conversion attributes for file-defining items, or the correlative, input-conversion, or output-conversion attributes for attribute-defining items.
output: Use the call processing code when you need custom logic that can't be achieved with standard processing codes. It's suitable for complex data validation, transformation, or business rules. Call subroutines from correlative fields for processing at file time, input-conversion for pre-processing before user access, or output-conversion for post-processing during display. The subroutines are Flash compiled for better performance.

instruction: How are parameters passed to subroutines called with the call processing code?
input: The syntax for calling a subroutine does not specify any parameters, but the subroutine is passed a parameter anyway, so one parameter must be specified in the subroutine statement. When a subroutine is called from the file-defining item, the entire item body is passed to the subroutine. When a subroutine is called from an attribute-defining item, the value of the calling attribute is passed to the subroutine.
output: Parameters are automatically passed to called subroutines: when called from a file-defining item, the entire item body is passed; when called from an attribute-defining item, only the current attribute value is passed. Your subroutine must specify one parameter in its declaration to receive this data, even though the call syntax doesn't show parameters explicitly.

instruction: Can you show me a practical example of a subroutine called by the call processing code?
input:
Example(s):
Assume that there is an attribute-defining item that contains a call to a subroutine called st.name:

subroutine st.name(st)
states = "alaska,washington,oregon,california,idaho"
codes = "al,wa,or,ca,id"
convert "," to char(254) in codes
locate(st,codes;x) then
st = field(states,",",x)
end else st = "unknown"

The value is passed from AQL into the st variable. If the corresponding string is found, st is loaded with the appropriate code and control returns to AQL.
output:
Here's a state code conversion example:

subroutine st.name(st)
states = "alaska,washington,oregon,california,idaho"
codes = "al,wa,or,ca,id"
convert "," to char(254) in codes
locate(st,codes;x) then
st = field(states,",",x)
end else st = "unknown"

This subroutine receives a state code (like "al"), looks it up in the codes list, and returns the full state name ("alaska") or "unknown" if not found.

instruction: How do I convert dates between internal and external formats using the d processing code?
input:
Syntax: d {yr.pos}{options|outsep}

The d processing code invokes the date conversion function to convert an external date to internal format, or more commonly, to convert an internal date to one of many available output formats. By convention, day 0 (in internal format) on the D3 calendar is December 31, 1967.
output: The d processing code converts dates between internal (days since 12/31/67) and external formats. Use it with various options like yr.pos for year digits (0-4), format options (d for day, m for month, y for year, etc.), or output separators (-, /, etc.). For example, 'd2' shows 2-digit years, 'd-' uses dash separators, and 'dma' shows alphabetic months.

instruction: What are the different date format options available with the d processing code?
input:
Parameter(s):
options - Character options are defined as:
d - Numeric day of the month (1 through 31)
f - Full external date with alphabetic month
j - Julian day of the year (1 through 366)
m - Numeric month (1 through 12)
ma - Alphabetic month (January, February, and so on)
q - Numeric quarter (1 through 4)
w - Numeric day of the week (1=Monday, 2=Tuesday, etc.)
wa - Alphabetic day of week (Sunday, Monday, and so on)
y - Year (default is four digits)
output: The d processing code offers various format options: 'd' for numeric day (1-31), 'f' for full date with alphabetic month, 'j' for Julian day (1-366), 'm' for numeric month (1-12), 'ma' for alphabetic month names, 'q' for quarter (1-4), 'w' for numeric weekday (1=Monday), 'wa' for alphabetic weekday names, and 'y' for year display. You can combine these options for custom date formatting.

instruction: Show me examples of different date conversion outputs
output:
Here are date conversion examples for internal date 10594:
- d0: 01 Jan 1997 (no year digits specified)
- d2-: 01-01-97 (2-digit year with dash separator)
- d-: 01-01-1997 (4-digit year with dash separator)
- dd: 1 (day number only)
- dm: 1 (month number only)
- dma: January (alphabetic month)
- dq: 1 (quarter number)
- dw: 3 (weekday number, Wednesday)
- dwa: Wednesday (alphabetic weekday)
- dy: 1997 (year only)

instruction: What input date formats are accepted when using the d processing code?
input:
The following table provides the valid formats to input dates through the Update processor or when using the d processing code in an iconv statement:

Format | Description
mm/dd/yy | Default and any separator may be used
mm/dd | Year is the same as the system date
mmdd | Year is the same as the system date
dd | Month and year are the same as the system date
dd/mm/yy | European format
ddd | Julian date (1 through 366)
yyddd | Julian date (five digits)
output: The d processing code accepts various input formats: mm/dd/yy (default with any separator), mm/dd (assumes current year), mmdd (assumes current year), dd (assumes current month/year), dd/mm/yy (European format), ddd (Julian day 1-366), and yyddd (5-digit Julian). You can also enter '.' to repeat the last date or '/' for today's date in the Update processor.

instruction: How do I set up a dependent attribute that's controlled by another attribute in a MultiValue pair?
input: The d processing code defines the dependent attribute in a control/dependent pair of correlated MultiValues; the controlling attribute must contain a c code. The attribute count specified in the attribute count parameter must contain the c code and attribute count of the controlling attribute. Note that this function belongs in attribute 4 of the item. Syntax: d;ac where ac specifies the attribute count of the controlling attribute.
output: To set up a dependent attribute in a MultiValue pair, use the d processing code with syntax d;ac where 'ac' is the attribute count of the controlling attribute. The controlling attribute must have a c code, and this d code goes in attribute 4 of the item. For example, if attribute 3 is the controlling attribute with c;4;5;6, then attributes 4, 5, and 6 would each contain d;3 to indicate they depend on attribute 3.

instruction: What's the purpose of the d processing code in MultiValue correlations?
input: The d processing code defines the dependent attribute in a control/dependent pair of correlated MultiValues; the controlling attribute must contain a c code. Example: In the example below, order# is the controlling attribute and controls the values in attributes 4, 5, and 6. Each of these three controlled attributes must indicate in their corresponding attribute-defining items that they are dependent upon attribute 3. id: order# quantity price ext.price 001 a a a a 002 3 4 5 6 003 004 c;4;5;6 d;3 d;3 d;3
output: The d processing code defines a dependent attribute in correlated MultiValue pairs. It creates a relationship where one attribute (with c code) controls multiple dependent attributes (with d codes). In the example, attribute 3 (order#) controls attributes 4, 5, and 6 using c;4;5;6, while each dependent attribute uses d;3 to reference the controlling attribute. This ensures the values remain synchronized across related attributes.

instruction: When working with correlated MultiValues, which attribute should contain the d code?
input: The d processing code defines the dependent attribute in a control/dependent pair of correlated MultiValues; the controlling attribute must contain a c code. The attribute count specified in the attribute count parameter must contain the c code and attribute count of the controlling attribute. Note that this function belongs in attribute 4 of the item.
output: The d processing code should be placed in attribute 4 of the dependent attribute's defining item. The dependent attributes use the d code to reference their controlling attribute, while the controlling attribute uses the c code to specify which attributes it controls.

instruction: How can I extract specific groups of characters separated by delimiters from a string?
input: The g processing code extracts one or more groups of contiguous character substrings delimited by the specified character. Syntax: g{skip.segments} delimiter get.segments. Parameters: skip.segments specifies the number of delimited groups to skip before performing the extraction. If omitted, zero is assumed, and extraction occurs from the beginning of the value. delimiter is any single printable character excluding integers and these characters: _segment mark (SM) ^attribute mark (AM) ]value mark (VM) \subvalue mark (SVM). get.segments specifies the number of contiguous groups to extract from the value.
output: Use the g processing code with syntax g{skip.segments}delimiter{get.segments}. The skip.segments parameter tells how many groups to skip (defaults to 0), delimiter is the character separating groups (cannot be integers or system marks), and get.segments specifies how many groups to extract. For example, with string 'ca*92714*1000', g*1 extracts 'ca', g1*2 extracts '92714*1000', and g2*1 extracts '1000'.

instruction: What are the results of different g code combinations on the string 'ca*92714*1000'?
input: The g processing code extracts one or more groups of contiguous character substrings delimited by the specified character. Example: The example below illustrates the results obtained from various combinations of the g code if the value being processed was the string: ca*92714*1000 g*1 ca g0*1 ca g*3 ca*92714*1000 g1*2 92714*1000 g2*1 1000 g2*2 1000 g3*1 (null)
output: For the string 'ca*92714*1000' with asterisk as delimiter: g*1 returns 'ca' (first group), g0*1 also returns 'ca' (skip 0, get 1), g*3 returns 'ca*92714*1000' (all 3 groups), g1*2 returns '92714*1000' (skip 1, get 2), g2*1 returns '1000' (skip 2, get 1), g2*2 returns '1000' (skip 2, get 2 but only 1 remains), and g3*1 returns null (skip 3, nothing left).

instruction: Is it possible to use system marks as delimiters in the g processing code?
input: The g processing code extracts one or more groups of contiguous character substrings delimited by the specified character. Parameters: delimiter is any single printable character excluding integers and these characters: _segment mark (SM) ^attribute mark (AM) ]value mark (VM) \subvalue mark (SVM).
output: No, you cannot use system marks as delimiters in the g processing code. The delimiter must be any single printable character but specifically excludes integers and these system characters: _ (segment mark), ^ (attribute mark), ] (value mark), and \ (subvalue mark).

instruction: How do I create a local index for an attribute and make it usable with the Update processor?
input: The i processing code indicates that an index exists for the current attribute. It must be defined in the attribute-defining item that corresponds to a local B-tree index previously created with a create-index command. This processing code is supported only from the VME. Example: Create an index on attribute 1: create-index filename a1. The i processing code must be added to the input-conversion attribute of the corresponding attribute-defining item before the index may be used by the Update processor.
output: First create the index using 'create-index filename a1', then add the 'i' processing code to the input-conversion attribute (attribute 14) of the corresponding attribute-defining item. This makes the index available to the Update processor. The i code simply indicates that an index exists for that attribute and is only supported from the VME.

instruction: What's required before using the i processing code?
input: The i processing code indicates that an index exists for the current attribute. It must be defined in the attribute-defining item that corresponds to a local B-tree index previously created with a create-index command. This processing code is supported only from the VME.
output: Before using the i processing code, you must have previously created a local B-tree index using the create-index command. The i code must then be defined in the attribute-defining item that corresponds to this index. Additionally, this processing code is only supported from the VME (Virtual Machine Environment).

instruction: Can I create an index that combines multiple attributes?
input: The i processing code indicates that an index exists for the current attribute. Example: Create an index consisting of attribute 1 concatenated with attribute 2: create-index filename a1:2
output: Yes, you can create an index that combines multiple attributes by using a colon separator. For example, 'create-index filename a1:2' creates an index consisting of attribute 1 concatenated with attribute 2.

instruction: How does conditional processing work in dictionary attributes?
input: The if processing code is used in dictionary attributes 7 and 8 (conversion and correlative) to generate values based on results of evaluation of expression according to the rules of a-correlative construction. The if processing code is a stand-alone version of the if conditional allowable within an a-correlative. If the condition evaluates to true (nonzero) the a-correlative following then is executed. If there is no then clause a null value is returned on true. If the condition evaluates to 0 (false), the else clause is taken. Multiple complex conditionals can be constructed by using end to close the current if clause and associate else with the prior if clause. Syntax: if condition{then a-correlative} {else a-correlative} {end}
output: The if processing code enables conditional logic in dictionary attributes 7 and 8. It evaluates a condition and executes the 'then' clause if true (nonzero) or the 'else' clause if false (0). If no 'then' clause exists, it returns null on true. You can build complex nested conditionals using 'end' to close if clauses. For example: 'if 2#4 then 4:'**':2' concatenates field 4 with '**' and field 2 if the condition is true.

instruction: What happens when an if condition evaluates to false?
input: The if processing code is used in dictionary attributes 7 and 8 (conversion and correlative) to generate values based on results of evaluation of expression according to the rules of a-correlative construction. If the condition evaluates to 0 (false), the else clause is taken. Examples: if 2#4 then 4:'**':2, if 14["1","3"]='sco' then 17
output: When an if condition evaluates to 0 (false), the else clause is executed. If no else clause is specified, the result depends on the context. The condition follows a-correlative construction rules for evaluation.

instruction: Give me an example of using the if processing code with field comparisons.
input: The if processing code is used in dictionary attributes 7 and 8 (conversion and correlative) to generate values based on results of evaluation of expression according to the rules of a-correlative construction. Examples: if 2#4 then 4:'**':2, if 14["1","3"]='sco' then 17
output: Here are examples of if processing code usage: 'if 2#4 then 4:'**':2' checks if field 2 equals field 4, and if true, concatenates field 4 with '**' and field 2. 'if 14["1","3"]='sco' then 17' checks if values 1 and 3 of field 14 equal 'sco', and if true, returns field 17.

instruction: How can I restrict output based on string length or get the length of a field?
input: The l processing code either restricts processing to values that fall within certain length restrictions or displays the length of a given value. Syntax: Ln{,m}. Parameters: n - The value will be output only if the length of the string is equal to the specified length; otherwise a null is returned. If the length specified is 0, the length of the data is returned. If a maximum (m) length is specified, then n represents the minimum length and the value will be output only if the length of the string is equal to or greater than the minimum value and equal to or less than the maximum value. m - If specified, the value will be output only if the length of the string is equal to or greater than the minimum specification (n) and equal to or less than m.
output: Use the l processing code with syntax Ln{,m}. If n=0 (L0), it returns the actual length of the data. For exact length matching, use Ln (e.g., L9 outputs data only if exactly 9 characters). For range matching, use Ln,m (e.g., L3,9 outputs data only if length is between 3 and 9 characters inclusive). If the length criteria isn't met, null is returned.

instruction: What does L0 return when used as a processing code?
input: The l processing code either restricts processing to values that fall within certain length restrictions or displays the length of a given value. Parameters: If the length specified is 0, the length of the data is returned. Example: Returns the total field length of all characters in the field. L0
output: L0 returns the total field length of all characters in the field. When the length parameter is specified as 0, instead of filtering based on length, it returns the actual length of the data as a numeric value.

instruction: Under what conditions would L3,9 output data versus return null?
input: The l processing code either restricts processing to values that fall within certain length restrictions or displays the length of a given value. Example: Outputs data if the field length is greater than or equal to three characters and less than or equal to nine. L3,9
output: L3,9 outputs the original data if the field length is between 3 and 9 characters inclusive (greater than or equal to 3 AND less than or equal to 9). If the field length is less than 3 characters or greater than 9 characters, it returns null instead of the data.

instruction: When would I use L9 versus L3,9 for length validation?
input: The l processing code either restricts processing to values that fall within certain length restrictions or displays the length of a given value. Examples: Outputs data if the field length is exactly nine characters. L9. Outputs data if the field length is greater than or equal to three characters and less than or equal to nine. L3,9
output: Use L9 when you need exactly 9 characters - it outputs data only if the length is precisely 9, returning null otherwise. Use L3,9 when you need a range - it outputs data if the length is anywhere from 3 to 9 characters inclusive. L9 is for exact matching, while L3,9 provides flexibility within a range.

instruction: How do I format numeric data with decimal places and thousand separators?
input: The m processing code is a masking conversion used for both numeric and text string formatting. This conversion is quite complex because nearly all of the elements available in its syntax are optional. The elements are listed in the order that the system evaluates the expression. Syntax: m{l|r} {{precision} {scalefactor}} {z} {,} {signcode} {$} {format.mask}. Parameters: l|r indicates justification (l for left, r for right), precision indicates number of decimal positions (0-9), scalefactor indicates power for descaling (0-9), z suppresses leading zeros, comma inserts commas in thousands positions, signcode alters negative number handling, $ appends dollar sign.
output: Use the m processing code with syntax m{l|r}{{precision}{scalefactor}}{z}{,}{signcode}{$}{format.mask}. For example: mr2,$ formats right-justified with 2 decimal places, commas for thousands, and dollar sign. The elements must be in order: justification (l/r), precision/scale, zero suppression (z), comma insertion (,), sign handling, dollar sign ($), and format mask.

instruction: What's the difference between precision and scalefactor in the m processing code?
input: The m processing code is a masking conversion used for both numeric and text string formatting. Parameters: precision indicates the number of decimal positions to print after the decimal point (0-9), defaults to 0. scalefactor indicates the power to which the value is to be descaled (0-9), no default. When precision is specified without scalefactor, scalefactor defaults to precision value (mr2 is identical to mr22). Example: an internally stored number is 56789 with four implied decimals. The mask mr4 indicates both scalefactor and precision are 4, returning 5.6789. For mr24, first scales by 4 then rounds to two decimals resulting in 5.68.
output: Precision determines how many decimal places to display (0-9), while scalefactor determines how many decimal places to shift the internal value (0-9). If you specify precision without scalefactor, scalefactor defaults to the precision value. For example, with internal value 56789 (4 implied decimals): mr4 shows 5.6789 (scale by 4, show 4 decimals), while mr24 shows 5.68 (scale by 4, but show only 2 decimals with rounding).

instruction: Show me examples of different m processing code formatting options.
input: The m processing code is a masking conversion used for both numeric and text string formatting. Example data showing effect of passing values through oconv function: Data=12345, Conversion=mr2, Output=123.45; Data=123456, Conversion=mr2,$$, Output=$1,234.56; Data=-123456, Conversion=mr2,e, Output=<1,234.56>; Data=-123456, Conversion=mr2,c, Output=1,234.56cr; Data=7145551212, Conversion=ml((###)###-####), Output=(714)555-1212
output: Here are examples of m processing code formatting: mr2 converts 12345 to 123.45 (2 decimal places), mr2,$$ converts 123456 to $1,234.56 (currency with commas), mr2,e converts -123456 to <1,234.56> (negative in brackets), mr2,c converts -123456 to 1,234.56cr (credit notation), and ml((###)###-####) converts 7145551212 to (714)555-1212 (phone number format with literal mask).

instruction: Why should I be cautious when using mask conversions with AQL selection criteria?
input: The m processing code is a masking conversion used for both numeric and text string formatting. CAUTION: The functionality for mask and date conversions is not intuitive when combined with selection criteria in an AQL sentence. If a mask or date conversion exists in the output-conversion, that conversion is applied to the selection criteria in an AQL statement. For instance, in the sentence: select filename with attr "90]" where the data contains values as 9000, 9010, 9020, the "90]" is converted by an mr2 to "9000]". The logic is to convert the selection criteria once, rather than converting each value processed by the select command. Moving the mr2 to the correlative attribute bypasses the conversion to the selection criteria.
output: Be cautious because mask conversions in output-conversion attributes are applied to selection criteria in AQL statements, not just to output formatting. For example, if you have mr2 in output-conversion and search for "90]", it gets converted to "9000]" before comparison. This can cause unexpected results. To avoid this, move the mr2 to the correlative attribute instead, which bypasses the conversion of selection criteria while still formatting the output.

instruction: How can I extract only alphabetic characters from a mixed string?
input: The mc processing code invokes one of many available processing codes for special processing on numeric and alphabetic strings of characters. Multiple mc conversions may be placed on the same attribute in an attribute-defining item, provided that each is delimited by a value mark. Syntax: mc{/}code. Parameters: code strings include: a (retrieves only alphabetic characters), n (retrieves only numeric characters), /a (retrieves only nonalphabetic characters), /n (retrieves only nonnumeric characters), /an (retrieves only characters that are neither alphabetical nor numerical). Example: string = "1200 Main Street", oconv(string,"mca") outputs "MainStreet" (numbers and embedded spaces are stripped).
output: Use the mc processing code with 'a' parameter: mca. This extracts only alphabetic characters from the input string. For example, oconv("1200 Main Street","mca") returns "MainStreet", removing all numbers and spaces. You can combine multiple mc conversions on the same attribute by separating them with value marks.

instruction: What's the difference between mc/a and mca processing codes?
input: The mc processing code invokes processing codes for special processing on numeric and alphabetic strings. Parameters: /a retrieves only the nonalphabetic characters from a given data value, a retrieves only the alphabetic characters from a given data value. Examples: string = "1200 Main Street", oconv(string,"mc/a") outputs "1200 " (1200 followed by two spaces), oconv(string,"mca") outputs "MainStreet".
output: mc/a retrieves only NONalphabetic characters (numbers, spaces, punctuation), while mca retrieves only alphabetic characters (letters). For "1200 Main Street": mc/a returns "1200 " (the numbers and spaces), while mca returns "MainStreet" (just the letters). The slash (/) inverts the selection criteria.

instruction: How do I convert between uppercase and lowercase using mc codes?
input: The mc processing code invokes processing codes for special processing on numeric and alphabetic strings. Parameters: l converts all characters to lowercase, u converts all characters to uppercase, s capitalizes first letter in each sentence, t capitalizes first character after any nonalphabetic character. Examples: oconv("UPPER And lower","mcl") displays "upper and lower", oconv("UPPER And lower","mcu") displays "UPPER AND LOWER".
output: Use mcl to convert to lowercase and mcu to convert to uppercase. For example: mcl converts "UPPER And lower" to "upper and lower", while mcu converts it to "UPPER AND LOWER". You can also use mcs to capitalize the first letter of each sentence, or mct to capitalize the first character after any nonalphabetic character.

instruction: Is it possible to convert between hexadecimal and decimal using mc codes?
input: The mc processing code invokes processing codes for special processing on numeric and alphabetic strings. Parameters: dx converts all decimal numbers to their corresponding hexadecimal equivalent, xd converts all hexadecimal numbers to their corresponding decimal equivalent. Examples: number = 10, oconv(number,"mcdx") displays "A", oconv("1AF2","mcxd") outputs "6898".
output: Yes, you can convert between hexadecimal and decimal using mc codes. Use mcdx to convert decimal to hexadecimal (e.g., 10 becomes "A"), and mcxd to convert hexadecimal to decimal (e.g., "1AF2" becomes "6898"). These conversions work on all decimal/hexadecimal numbers within the given value.

instruction: How do I convert time values between internal and external formats?
input: The mt processing code invokes the time conversion function to convert external time representations to internal format or to convert internal time values to one of a variety of external time formats. The internal time format is the number of seconds from midnight. The external time format is 24-hour military format (23:25:59) or 12-hour format (11:25:59PM). For input-conversion, time is entered with am or pm immediately following the numeric time. If none is entered, am is assumed. On output, am or pm is always printed. When used as input-conversion, mt validates the time and converts to internal format. When updating a field controlled by mt conversion, the / character can be used to insert the current time. Syntax: mt{h}{s}
output: The mt processing code converts between internal time (seconds from midnight) and external time formats. For input, use external formats like "11:25:59PM" or "23:25:59" - if no am/pm is specified, am is assumed. The code validates and converts to internal seconds. For output, it converts internal seconds to readable time format. Use 'h' parameter for 12-hour format with am/pm, 's' parameter to include seconds. You can insert current time using the '/' character during updates.

instruction: What are the parameter options for the mt processing code?
input: The mt processing code invokes the time conversion function. Syntax: mt{h}{s}. Parameters: h specifies a 12-hour clock, default is (military) 24-hour clock. When specifying the h parameter, the range of values for internal format representation are from 0 to 86399. s includes seconds in output value. If omitted, seconds are not listed on output.
output: The mt processing code has two optional parameters: 'h' for 12-hour clock format (default is 24-hour military time) with am/pm indicators, and 's' to include seconds in the output (omitted by default). You can combine them, like mths for 12-hour format with seconds. The internal representation ranges from 0 to 86399 seconds (24 hours worth).

instruction: Show me examples of mt processing code output for different time values.
input: The mt processing code invokes the time conversion function. Examples: Data=3600, Code=mt, Output=01:00; Data=3600, Code=mth, Output=01:00am; Data=3600, Code=mts, Output=01:00:00; Data=3600, Code=mths, Output=01:00:00am; Data=46800, Code=mt, Output=13:00; Data=46800, Code=mth, Output=01:00pm; Data=3630, Code=mts, Output=01:00:30; Data=46800, Code=mths, Output=01:00:00pm

instruction: How do I convert ASCII text to hexadecimal representation?
input: The mx processing code converts all ASCII characters in a given value to their corresponding ASCII-hexadecimal equivalent. The characters are converted one at a time to 2-digit hexadecimal numbers. The my code is the inverse of the mx code. Examples: Data=123, Conversion=mx, Output=313233; Data=abc, Conversion=mx, Output=616263; Data="a dog", Conversion=mx, Output=6120646F67
output: Use the mx processing code to convert ASCII characters to hexadecimal. Each ASCII character becomes a 2-digit hex number. For example: "123" becomes "313233" (3=31, 1=31, 2=32, 3=33 in hex), "abc" becomes "616263" (a=61, b=62, c=63), and "a dog" becomes "6120646F67" (including the space as hex 20). The my code reverses this conversion.

instruction: What's the relationship between mx and my processing codes?
input: The mx processing code converts all ASCII characters in a given value to their corresponding ASCII-hexadecimal equivalent. The my code is the inverse of the mx code. The my processing code converts all ASCII hexadecimal characters in a given value to their corresponding ASCII equivalent. The characters are converted two at a time to 1-digit ASCII characters. The mx code is the inverse of the my code.
output: The mx and my processing codes are inverses of each other. mx converts ASCII characters to hexadecimal (each character becomes 2 hex digits), while my converts hexadecimal back to ASCII characters (every 2 hex digits become 1 ASCII character). For example: "abc" with mx becomes "616263", and "616263" with my becomes "abc".

instruction: Can you show me examples of my processing code converting hex back to ASCII?

The characters are converted two at a time to 1-digit ASCII characters.
