instruction: How do I set up a subindex that updates when translate file values change?
input: The s (Subindex) processing code is used to update an index that uses a file translation if the value in the translate file changes. This processing code is set from Attribute 8 of the File Definition Item for the data section of a translate file. Syntax: s<File1>;<AMC>;a<n>(t<File2>;<c>;;<AMC>). Parameters: <File1> is a file having the index, <AMC> is the attribute in the translate item containing the translated data, <n> is the primary attribute number for the index, <File2> is the translate file, <c> is the translate subcode.
output: To set up a subindex for translate file updates, place the s processing code in attribute 8 of the translate file's File Definition Item. Use syntax s<File1>;<AMC>;a<n>(t<File2>;<c>;;<AMC>) where File1 has the index, AMC is the translate data attribute, n is the indexed attribute number, File2 is the translate file, and c is the subcode. This automatically updates the main file's index when translate file values change.

instruction: Walk me through the subindex processing code example step by step.
input: The s (Subindex) processing code example: CREATE-FILE MYMAIN 1 1, CREATE-FILE MYTRANS 1 1, CREATE-INDEX MYMAIN A1(TMYTRANS;X;;1). Put the subindex processing code on attribute 8 of DICT MYTRANS MYTRANS: sMYMAIN;1;A1(TMYTRANS;X;;1). Create items in MYTRANS: item 1 contains 'same', item 2 contains 'diff'. Create items in MYMAIN: items a,c reference translate item 1, items b,d reference translate item 2. Initially index order is b,d,a,c since 'diff' sorts before 'same'. After changing item 2 from 'diff' to 'update', index order becomes a,c,b,d since 'same' sorts before 'update'.
output: The example demonstrates automatic index maintenance: 1) Create main file MYMAIN and translate file MYTRANS, 2) Create index on MYMAIN referencing MYTRANS, 3) Add subindex code sMYMAIN;1;A1(TMYTRANS;X;;1) to MYTRANS definition, 4) MYTRANS has items 1='same' and 2='diff', 5) MYMAIN items a,c point to MYTRANS item 1, items b,d point to item 2, 6) Index initially orders as b,d,a,c (diff < same), 7) When MYTRANS item 2 changes to 'update', index automatically reorders to a,c,b,d (same < update).

instruction: What files and commands are needed to implement the subindex processing code?
input: The s (Subindex) processing code example shows: CREATE-FILE MYMAIN 1 1, CREATE-FILE MYTRANS 1 1, CREATE-INDEX MYMAIN A1(TMYTRANS;X;;1), then put sMYMAIN;1;A1(TMYTRANS;X;;1) on attribute 8 of DICT MYTRANS MYTRANS.
output: To implement subindex processing, you need: 1) CREATE-FILE for the main data file (MYMAIN), 2) CREATE-FILE for the translate file (MYTRANS), 3) CREATE-INDEX on the main file that references the translate file using the translate syntax A1(TMYTRANS;X;;1), 4) Add the subindex processing code sMYMAIN;1;A1(TMYTRANS;X;;1) to attribute 8 of the translate file's dictionary definition.

instruction: How would I implement a running subtotal in an AQL listing that resets at control breaks?
input: The xr processing code produces a running subtotal of an output column on an AQL listing or report. The attribute definition must have xr specified as an output-conversion (attribute 7) only. In order to get a running total, the attribute containing the xr conversion code must be totaled. If not, the conversion has no effect. Syntax: xr{break.level}. Parameter: break.level specifies the control break level for a running subtotal.
output: Use the xr processing code in the output-conversion (attribute 7) of your attribute definition. The syntax is xr{break.level} where break.level specifies the control break level for the running subtotal. The attribute containing the xr conversion code must be totaled in your AQL statement, otherwise the conversion has no effect. This processing code is only effective from AQL.

instruction: What does the xr1 processing code accomplish when used in an AQL total clause?
input: Example: Assume that the processing code below was present in the output-conversions of the attribute-defining item myattr: xr1. This causes any AQL statements using this attribute in a total clause to reset the running total to 0 after the first and higher break levels.
output: The xr1 processing code causes any AQL statements using this attribute in a total clause to reset the running total to 0 after the first and higher break levels. This means the running subtotal will restart from zero whenever a control break occurs at level 1 or higher.

instruction: Is it possible to use the xr processing code outside of AQL queries?
input: CAUTION: This processing code is only effective from AQL. For compatibility reasons, a subvalue mark is allowed before the break level.
output: No, the xr processing code is only effective from AQL queries. It cannot be used outside of AQL. However, for compatibility reasons, a subvalue mark is allowed before the break level specification.

instruction: Under what conditions does the xr conversion code have no effect on output?
input: In order to get a running total, the attribute containing the xr conversion code must be totaled. If not, the conversion has no effect.
output: The xr conversion code has no effect if the attribute containing it is not totaled in the AQL statement. To get a running total, you must include the attribute with the xr conversion code in a total clause of your AQL query.

instruction: How do I invoke the Runoff processor to output documents from a file?
input: The runoff command invokes the output function of the Runoff processor. Syntax: runoff file.reference itemlist*{(options)}. Parameters: file.reference - File that contains the items specified in itemlist. itemlist* - Chains items to other items within the same item list.
output: Use the runoff command with the syntax: runoff file.reference itemlist*{(options)}. Specify the file.reference containing your items and the itemlist of items to process. You can chain items to other items within the same item list using the asterisk notation.

instruction: What options are available when running the runoff command for output control?
input: Options: c - Suppresses the .chain and .read commands. i - Outputs the name of the next item-ID to be output. j - Suppresses highlights. n - Prevents pausing at page breaks when outputting to the terminal. number - Sets the number of times boldface or underscore characters are printed. p - Directs output to system printer, via the Spooler. s - Suppresses boldface, underline, fonts, and default headings. u - Forces all output to uppercase.
output: The runoff command supports several options: (c) suppresses .chain and .read commands, (i) outputs the next item-ID name, (j) suppresses highlights, (n) prevents pausing at page breaks for terminal output, (number) sets repetition count for boldface/underscore, (p) directs output to system printer via Spooler, (s) suppresses formatting like boldface and fonts, and (u) forces all output to uppercase.

instruction: Show me examples of how to use the runoff command with different options.
input: Examples: runoff doc chainletter (c, runoff doc, runoff doc termination.notice (ps
output: Here are runoff command examples: 'runoff doc chainletter (c' processes chainletter from the doc file while suppressing .chain and .read commands. 'runoff doc' processes all items from the doc file with default settings. 'runoff doc termination.notice (ps' processes termination.notice from doc file, directing output to the printer and suppressing formatting.

instruction: How would I enable underline mode in Runoff text formatting?
input: The &^ function puts Runoff in underline mode until an &\ is encountered. Syntax: &^
output: Use the &^ function to put Runoff in underline mode. The underline formatting continues until you encounter an &\ which terminates the underline mode.

instruction: Can you demonstrate the &^ function with a practical example?
input: Example: &^Special Control Characters&\ are needed
output: Here's an example: '&^Special Control Characters&\ are needed' - this will underline the text 'Special Control Characters' while leaving 'are needed' in normal formatting.

instruction: When should I use the _ function in Runoff text processing?
input: The _ function treats the following character as a text character, rather than as a control character. Syntax: _
output: Use the _ function when you need to treat a character as literal text instead of as a Runoff control character. This is useful when you want to display characters that would normally be interpreted as commands or formatting codes.

instruction: How do I print an actual underscore character in Runoff output?
input: Example: This prints one underscore: __.
output: To print an actual underscore character, use two underscores: '__'. The first underscore (_) acts as the escape function, treating the second underscore as a literal text character rather than a control character.

instruction: What's the purpose of the .* function in Runoff documents?
input: The .* function treats the entire line following the command as a remark. Any text following the command is not output by Runoff. Syntax: .* {text}
output: The .* function is used to create comments or remarks in Runoff documents. Any text following .* on the same line is treated as a remark and will not be output by Runoff, making it useful for documentation within your source files.

instruction: Give me an example of how to use .* for comments in Runoff.
input: Example: The following text is ignored. .* comments begin here.
output: Here's an example: 'The following text is ignored. .* comments begin here.' - In this case, 'The following text is ignored.' will be output normally, but everything after '.* comments begin here.' will be treated as a comment and ignored in the output.

instruction: How does the .begin page command work in Runoff document formatting?
input: The .begin page command executes a .break command followed by an advance to a new page. The page number is incremented and the page heading (if set) is printed. The .begin page command must begin in position one of the attribute. If it is in the middle of an attribute, it is ignored and printed as text.
output: The .begin page command terminates the current page, executes a break, advances to a new page, increments the page counter, and prints the optional heading. It must be positioned at the beginning of an attribute (position one) to function properly - if placed in the middle of an attribute, it will be treated as regular text.

instruction: What sequence of actions does .begin page trigger when processing a document?
input: The .begin page command terminates the current page, prints the optional footing, ejects a page, increments the page counter, and prints the optional heading.
output: The .begin page command triggers this sequence: 1) terminates the current page, 2) prints the optional footing, 3) ejects the page, 4) increments the page counter, and 5) prints the optional heading for the new page.

instruction: Can you show me a practical example of using .begin page in a document?
input: Example: .nf This is page one. .begin page This is page two attribute 1. This is page two attribute 2. .bp This is page three.
output: Here's an example: '.nf This is page one. .begin page This is page two attribute 1. This is page two attribute 2. .bp This is page three.' This creates 'This is page one.' on the first page, then '.begin page' starts a new page with 'This is page two attribute 1. This is page two attribute 2.', and '.bp' creates a third page with 'This is page three.'

instruction: How do I create a text box with defined margins in Runoff?
input: The .box command defines the left and right margin boundaries for a box around the text, and encloses the following text in a box of vertical bars on the output page. Syntax: .box left.margin, right.margin and .box off. Parameters: left.margin defines the left margin boundary, right.margin defines the right margin boundary.
output: Use the .box command with syntax '.box left.margin, right.margin' to define margin boundaries and enclose text in a box with vertical bars. Specify the left and right margin positions as parameters. Use '.box off' to turn off the box effect.

instruction: Show me how to implement a boxed note using the .box command.
output: Here's a boxed note example: '.nf .box 6,16 :----------------------------------------: : Note: This is a .box command example.  : :----------------------------------------: .box off' This creates a box with left margin at position 6 and right margin at position 16, containing the formatted note text, then turns off the box effect.

instruction: What does the .break command accomplish in Runoff text flow?
input: The .break command creates a new paragraph. The text following the .break command is output in the newly created paragraph. This is a method of flowing text, starting a new paragraph without a new attribute. The .break command may be placed anywhere within the document.
output: The .break command creates a new paragraph and flows the following text into it. It's a way to start a new paragraph without requiring a new attribute, and can be placed anywhere within the document to control text flow and paragraph breaks.

instruction: Can you demonstrate how .break affects text output formatting?
input: Example: For graphic representation see below: .break Example A. Produces the following output: For graphic representation see below: Example A.
output: Here's how .break works: 'For graphic representation see below: .break Example A' produces the output 'For graphic representation see below:' followed by 'Example A.' on a new line, demonstrating how .break creates a paragraph break in the text flow.

instruction: How does the .capitalize sentences command modify text output?
input: The .capitalize sentences command capitalizes sentences following a period, exclamation point, question mark, colon, or a semicolon that is followed by one or more spaces. If the first word of the sentence is already capitalized, it remains capitalized. The .nocapitalize sentences command disables the .capitalize sentences command.
output: The .capitalize sentences command automatically capitalizes the first word of sentences that follow punctuation marks (period, exclamation point, question mark, colon, or semicolon) when followed by spaces. Already capitalized words remain unchanged. Use .nocapitalize sentences to disable this feature.

instruction: Show me an example of automatic sentence capitalization in action.
input: Example: .capitalize sentences this is the first sentence. this is the second. And, this is the third. The output from this example is: This is the first sentence. This is the second. And, this is the third.
output: With '.capitalize sentences this is the first sentence. this is the second. And, this is the third.', the output becomes 'This is the first sentence. This is the second. And, this is the third.' Notice how 'this' gets capitalized after periods, while 'And' remains capitalized as it already was.

instruction: What does the .center command do to text positioning in Runoff?
input: The .center command outputs the next line of the document in nofill mode and centers it on the next line of output. This command causes a break (new paragraph) to occur.
output: The .center command centers the next line of text on the output page, processes it in nofill mode, and causes a paragraph break to occur. This is useful for centering headings or other single lines of text.

instruction: How would I center a heading using the .center command?
input: Example: .center                Heading A. Produces this output: Heading A
output: Use '.center' followed by your heading text: '.center                Heading A' will produce 'Heading A' centered on the output page. The spaces in the input are used for positioning in nofill mode, and the result is a centered heading.

instruction: How does the .chain command work for transferring control between documents?
input: The .chain command transfers control to the specified item-ID. This command is particularly useful for generating form letters. A select statement is used to extract relevant data from the file and save it in a list. A series of .readnext statements inserts the data into the text of the letter. At the end of the letter, a .chain command may be used to restart the next letter.
output: The .chain command transfers control to a specified item-ID, making it useful for form letter generation. You can use select statements to extract data into lists, use .readnext statements to insert data into letter text, and use .chain to process the next letter. When the list is exhausted, Runoff stops processing.

instruction: What are the parameters for the .chain command?
input: Parameters: file.reference - Specifies the file where the item change resides. If not specified, the current file is used. Control does not return to the source item. item-ID - Specifies the item to transfer control to. Syntax: .chain {file.reference} item-ID
output: The .chain command takes an optional file.reference parameter (defaults to current file if omitted) and a required item-ID parameter. The syntax is '.chain {file.reference} item-ID'. Important: control does not return to the source item after the chain operation completes.

instruction: Can you show me a practical example of using .chain?
input: Example: .chain next.doc. The item next.doc is processed at the end of the document that called it.
output: Here's an example: '.chain next.doc' will transfer control to the item 'next.doc', which gets processed at the end of the current document. Control flows to next.doc and doesn't return to the calling document.

instruction: What does the .contents command generate in a Runoff document?
input: The .contents command outputs the current table of contents, as defined by the previous .chapter and .section commands.
output: The .contents command generates and outputs a table of contents based on the .chapter and .section commands that have been used previously in the document. It creates a formatted listing of chapters and sections with their corresponding page numbers.

instruction: Show me how .contents works with chapter definitions.
input: Example: .chapter Runoff .chapter OP .contents. The output of this example is: Chapter 1 Runoff (page eject) Chapter 2 OP (page eject) Table of Contents section page 1 Runoff 1 2 OP 2
output: With '.chapter Runoff .chapter OP .contents', you get 'Chapter 1 Runoff' on page 1, 'Chapter 2 OP' on page 2 (with page ejects between), followed by a 'Table of Contents' showing 'section page 1 Runoff 1 2 OP 2'. The .contents command formats this automatically based on the preceding .chapter commands.

instruction: How do I disable case conversion commands in Runoff?
input: The .end case command disables any previous .upper case or .lower case commands.
output: Use the .end case command to disable any previously active .upper case or .lower case commands, returning text processing to normal case handling.

instruction: What's the relationship between .end case and other case commands?
input: Example: .upper case this is the first sentence. this is the second. .end case
output: In this example: '.upper case this is the first sentence. this is the second. .end case', the text 'this is the first sentence. this is the second.' would be converted to uppercase, but any text following .end case would return to normal case processing.

instruction: How does the .fill command affect text formatting in Runoff?
input: The .fill command enters line fill mode. Words are processed until there are enough to fill a line without overflowing it. If justification mode is on, Runoff inserts spaces in the line at random to make the right margin line up. The .fill command is one of the .standard command settings and the .nofill command is used to terminate the .fill command.
output: The .fill command enables line fill mode, where words are processed to fill lines without overflow. With justification enabled, Runoff randomly inserts spaces to align the right margin. .fill is a standard command setting, and you can disable it using the .nofill command.

instruction: Can you demonstrate the difference .fill makes in text output?
input: Example: .fill This prints on line one, and so does this. The output displays as: This prints on line one, and so does this.
output: With '.fill This prints on line one, and so does this.', the output becomes 'This prints on line one, and so does this.' The .fill command combines the text from multiple input lines into a single filled output line.

instruction: How do I set up page footings with various formatting options in Runoff?
input: The .footing command designates a text string composed of literals and special options to output at the bottom of each page. If the line following the .footing command is null, the footing is suppressed. The .footing command places the footing text in a buffer and is only processed during a break page. Syntax: .footing {{text} {'options'}...}
output: Use the .footing command to create page footings with literal text and special formatting options. The footing appears at the bottom of each page and is processed during page breaks. If you specify a null line after .footing, the footing is suppressed. The footing text is buffered until page break processing occurs.

instruction: What special options are available for .footing formatting?
input: Options: '' (Two single quotation marks.) Outputs (one) single quotation mark. 'attr.name' Inserts the value of attr.name. b Inserts the attribute name causing the break. c Centers the output line. d Retrieves the current date (dd mmm yyyy format). f{n} Inserts the file name in a field of n spaces. j Right-justifies the rest of the line. l Issues a carriage return/line feed. n Prevents the pause at the end of each page. p Retrieves the current page number, right-justified in a field of four spaces. r Retrieves the Roman numeral page number. t Retrieves the current time and date. u Toggles on underline mode. v Toggles on boldface mode.
output: The .footing command supports many formatting options: '' for literal quotes, 'attr.name' for attribute values, (c) for centering, (d) for date, (f{n}) for filename, (j) for right-justification, (l) for line feeds, (p) for page numbers, (r) for Roman numerals, (t) for time/date, (u) for underline, (v) for boldface, and various toggle options like (xc), (xs), (xu), (xv) to turn off formatting modes.

instruction: Show me a practical example of a formatted page footing.
input: Example: .footing "'lc'page 'pn' printed at 'tlc'"
output: Here's a footing example: '.footing "'lc'page 'pn' printed at 'tlc'"' creates a footing that outputs a line feed, centers the text, displays 'page' followed by the page number, then 'printed at' with the current time and date, followed by another centered line feed.

instruction: How does the .hilite command work for margin highlighting?
input: The .hilite command prints the optionally-specified character along the right margin. If the character is omitted, or the word off displays after the command, the .hilite command is disabled. The .hilite off command terminates the .hilite command. Syntax: .hilite {character} or .hilite off
output: The .hilite command prints a specified character along the right margin of your document. You can specify any character (except a period) as the highlight character. Use '.hilite off' or omit the character to disable highlighting.

instruction: Can you show me how to use .hilite for margin marking?

instruction: When should I use the .nocapitalize sentences command?

instruction: Explain the structure and purpose of the devs file.
input: This file, located on the dm account, has two data levels: The init data level contains static information that can be changed by the System Administrator to set up the various entities in the system. The devs data level contains dynamic information. The TCL command reset-async, normally runs at boot time in the system-coldstart macro, clears the devs,devs, file and copies the information from devs,init into devs,devs. The item-IDs in this file are the entity-IDs, which are composed of a one letter code followed by the entity number in decimal.
output: The devs file, located on the dm account, has two data levels: 'init' and 'devs'. The init level contains static configuration information that can be modified by the System Administrator, while the devs level contains dynamic information. The reset-async command (run at boot time) clears the devs,devs file and copies information from devs,init. Item-IDs are entity-IDs composed of a single letter code (like 'p' for D3 ports, 's' for serial devices) followed by the entity number in decimal.

instruction: What happens when the reset-async command runs?
input: This file, located on the dm account, has two data levels: The init data level contains static information that can be changed by the System Administrator to set up the various entities in the system. The devs data level contains dynamic information. The TCL command reset-async, normally runs at boot time in the system-coldstart macro, clears the devs,devs, file and copies the information from devs,init into devs,devs.
output: When the reset-async command runs (normally at boot time in the system-coldstart macro), it clears the devs,devs file and copies all the information from devs,init into devs,devs. This process refreshes the dynamic device information with the static configuration settings, ensuring that only physically present system elements are represented in the active devs file.

instruction: How are entity-IDs formatted in the devs file?
input: The item-IDs in this file are the entity-IDs, which are composed of a one letter code (p for D3 ports, s for serial device, e for Ethernet, and so on), followed by the entity number in decimal (the D3 port number, the serial device number, the TCP/IP connection-ID, and so on).
output: Entity-IDs in the devs file are composed of a single letter code followed by the entity number in decimal. The letter codes identify the type of entity: 'p' for D3 ports, 's' for serial devices, 'e' for Ethernet, etc. The number identifies the specific instance, such as the port number or device number. For example, 's12' would represent serial device 12.

instruction: What's the purpose of the hosts file in relation to super Q-pointers?

instruction: How does the hosts file help with MS-DOS drive access?

instruction: What does the iomap-file contain and how is it structured?
input: The data section of the file contains items that define the character translation. The dictionary level contains binary items that are compiled by the set-iomap command when used with the c option. Each item in the data section contains up to 33 attributes. Attribute 1 is used for comments. Attributes 2 through 33 contain data for the actual character translation.
output: The iomap-file contains character translation definitions and is structured with two levels: a data section and a dictionary level. The data section contains items with up to 33 attributes - attribute 1 for comments and attributes 2-33 for character translation data. The dictionary level contains binary items compiled by the set-iomap command with the 'c' option, with item-IDs preceded and followed by % signs.

instruction: How are ASCII characters organized in the iomap-file attributes?
input: Each attribute consists of 8 characters (32 x 8 = 256, the number of characters in the ASCII set). ASCII characters 0 through 7 (in hexadecimal) are stored in attribute 2. Characters 8 through 16 are stored in attribute 3, and so on.
output: ASCII characters in the iomap-file are organized across attributes 2-33, with each attribute containing 8 characters. ASCII characters 0-7 (hexadecimal) are stored in attribute 2, characters 8-15 in attribute 3, and so on. This arrangement covers all 256 ASCII characters (32 attributes Ã— 8 characters = 256 total characters).

This reads the specified item (1234) from the iomap-file data section, converts the ASCII character definitions into binary equivalents, and writes the compiled version as '%1234%' to the dictionary level of the iomap-file.

instruction: What types of items are stored in the keyboards file?
input: The keyboards file contains two types of items: Alternative keyboard definitions, including British, French, German, Italian, Spanish, and USA for PC-type systems, for the TCL command set-kbrd. Keyboard input translation items for the TCL command set-imap.

instruction: How do I define keyboard input translations using the IMAP format?
input: The format of the keyboard input translation for set-imap is: Attribute one must contain the keyword IMAP, optionally followed by one or more modifiers, separated by spaces. output: To define keyboard input translations using IMAP format, start with attribute 1 containing the keyword 'IMAP' optionally followed by modifiers separated by spaces. Then define translations on separate lines using the format "input sequence" : "converted sequence", where the input and output sequences are separated by a colon. Each line represents one key translation mapping.

instruction: What modifiers are available for IMAP keyboard definitions?
input: Attribute one must contain the keyword IMAP, optionally followed by one or more modifiers, separated by spaces. Valid modifiers are: timeout, esc-data, xcs-on
output: Valid modifiers for IMAP keyboard definitions include 'timeout' (for setting timing parameters), 'esc-data' (for handling escape sequences), and 'xcs-on' (for keyboards that generate 8-bit characters). instruction: What is the relationship between the pibs file and system processes?
input: A pibs item is required for each process executing on the system. The items in the pibs file define the memory resident hooks of the process workspaces. The pibs file also defines the physical devices connected to the system's ports, such as terminals, printers, phantoms, or communication ports.

The port numbers serve as the item-IDs in the file.

instruction: How do pibs and devices files work together for device control?
input: Device control information is derived from the pibs file and the devices file. The pibs item specifies the device type and the devices item defines device characteristics and drive functions.

instruction: How does the var file provide access to TCL shell variables?
input: The var driver (most easily used via the var file in the dm account) provides access to TCL shell variables via a file interface. A read using the variable name as the item-ID returns the shell variable's contents. A write using the variable name as the item-ID is identical to running a TCL set on that variable.

You can read a variable's contents by using the variable name as the item-ID, write to a variable (equivalent to running 'TCL set'), and delete variables (equivalent to 'TCL unset'). This allows you to manipulate shell variables using normal file operations instead of TCL commands.

instruction: Is it possible to execute TCL commands through the var file interface?
input: A read using a TCL command surrounded by back-quotes executes the TCL command and returns the results as if those results had been stored in an item.
output: Yes, you can execute TCL commands through the var file interface by surrounding the command with back-quotes when reading. For example, reading from an item-ID like `'who'` executes the 'who' TCL command and returns the results as if they had been stored in an item. This provides a way to execute and capture TCL command output through the file interface.

instruction: How do I output text to the screen in a D3 macro without a trailing carriage return?
output: To output text without a trailing carriage return in a D3 macro, use the display statement with a + at the end of your message text. For example: `display main menu@(-14)+` will display the text and suppress the trailing form feed.

instruction: What's the purpose of the prompt statement in D3 macros?
output: The prompt statement in D3 macros is used to display a text message to the user and wait for their input to either continue or quit the process. Only 'c' (continue) or 'q' (quit) responses are accepted. For example, `prompt Insert first reel` will display 'Insert first reel -- Quit/Continue (q/c)?' and wait for user input.

instruction: When would I use the (n and (p options with TCL commands?
input:
Options (TCL)
Syntax: tcl.commands...(n tcl.commands...(p
The print (p and no pause (n options are the only standard options available to every TCL command. Options always display at the end of a TCL command and must be preceded by a left parenthesis.
output: Use the (n option to activate the no pause function on output to the terminal, preventing the system from pausing for user input during long outputs. Use the (p option to direct output to the system printer via the spooler. For example: `copy dm,bp, term-type (p` sends output to printer, while `block-print this is a test (n` prevents pausing during output.

instruction: How can I create conditional logic in D3 procedures?
input:

For conditional branching, the if-then-go construct is used. The if statement is a conditional branch statement in a paragraph or PROC.
output: Use the if-then-go construct for conditional branching in D3 procedures. You can compare strings or prompt for user input and branch based on the result. For example: `if <<Input a number between 1 and 10:>> > 5 then go greater` will prompt the user for input and branch to the 'greater' label if the input is greater than 5.

instruction: Is it possible to use shell variables in D3 commands, and how?
input:
@ shell variable
Syntax: @[{}]variable.name[}]|@[{]$variable.name[}] @'tcl.command'
The @ character indicates a D3 shell variable.
