output: Important safety considerations: 1) Changes won't affect processes with files currently open - those processes must close files or logoff. 2) Never add the X option to FSI accounts using set-dptr (A, as this will break the restore-accounts command. 3) File sensitivity cannot be changed after creation. Always ensure file integrity when enabling logging (+l) by using the d option.

instruction: How would I remove xy types from all files in selected accounts?
input:
Command: set-dptr
Example: select mds\nset-dptr -xy (a
Note: It is not necessary to select items in the mds file, which are real D-pointers. set-dptr ignores Q-pointers and items that do not look like D-pointers.
output: First run 'select mds' to select all accounts, then use 'set-dptr -xy (a' to remove both 'x' and 'y' types from all files in all selected accounts. The command automatically ignores Q-pointers and non-D-pointer items, processing only actual file D-pointers.

instruction: How do I configure a custom ESC key for level pushing?
input:
Command: set-esc
Syntax: set-esc {argument} {(options}
Description: Specifies the value of the key to treat as the ESC key. This key subsequently pushes a level when pressed.
Example: set-esc 3 - Defines the ESC key as CTRL+C
output: Use 'set-esc 3' to define CTRL+C as the ESC key for level pushing. You can specify the key by its decimal value, hexadecimal value, or use keywords like 'esc' for normal ESC (x'1B') or 'off' to disable (x'ff'). The configured key will push a TCL level when pressed.

instruction: Why does set-esc warn against unreasonable key assignments?
input:
Command: set-esc
Warning: Assigning an unreasonable value to the ESC key, such as ENTER, will have unpredictable results.
output: Assigning commonly used keys like ENTER to the ESC function causes unpredictable system behavior because those keys are needed for normal operation. If ENTER were assigned as the ESC key, every attempt to press ENTER would push a level instead of executing commands or confirming input, making the system unusable.

instruction: When should I use set-file instead of direct path names?
input:
Command: set-file
Syntax: set-file {account.name{file.name}} {alternate.name}
Description: Creates or updates the synonym-defining item called qfile in the master dictionary. Provides access to the specified file name in the specified account.name by using the file name, qfile, in place of the file name parameter.
Note: The same functionality can be achieved using path names.
output: Use set-file when you want to create a convenient synonym 'qfile' for accessing files in other accounts without typing full path names repeatedly. While path names provide the same functionality, set-file creates a reusable shortcut. For example, 'set-file dm bp' lets you use 'qfile' instead of 'dm,bp' in subsequent commands.

instruction: What happens to previous Q-pointers when I run set-file?
input:
Command: set-file
Note: Each time set-file is invoked, it overwrites the previous Q-pointer.
output: Each execution of set-file overwrites the previous Q-pointer. This means you can only have one active qfile synonym at a time - creating a new one replaces the existing qfile definition in the master dictionary.

instruction: How do I attach a high-density 5.25-inch floppy drive?
input:
Command: set-floppy
Syntax: set-floppy {(density, drive)}
Example: set-floppy (ah - Attaches the floppy disk drive A at high density
Options: h (High density - 1.2 MB for 5.25-inch), a (Selects 5.25-inch floppy disk)
output: Use 'set-floppy (ah' to attach a 5.25-inch floppy drive at high density (1.2 MB). The 'a' option selects 5.25-inch drives, and 'h' specifies high density. Remember to use t-rew to rewind before any read/write operations.

instruction: What limitations exist when selecting between multiple floppy drives?
input:
Command: set-floppy
Description: This command does not allow selection among two devices of the same type. If two or more devices of the same type are present, the first one in the configuration file is selected.
output: The set-floppy command cannot distinguish between multiple drives of the same type - it will always select the first one listed in the configuration file. If you have two identical floppy drives and need to select a specific one, you'll need to use a different method or ensure the desired drive is listed first in the configuration.

instruction: How would I configure the system flush periods for optimal performance?
input:
Command: set-flush
Syntax: set-flush {{period}{,force.period}} {(options}
Description: Displays or changes the value of the period of the flush and of the forced flush.
Example: set-flush 30,off - Sets normal flush period to 30 seconds and disables forced flush
output: Use 'set-flush 30,off' to set the normal flush period to 30 seconds and disable forced flush. The first parameter (30) controls how often dirty frames are written to disk (0.5-32 seconds range). The second parameter controls forced flush: use 'off' or -1 to disable, 'imm' or 0 for immediate, or a number for guaranteed write time.

instruction: What's the difference between normal flush and forced flush?
input:
Command: set-flush
Parameters: period - flush process wakes up automatically to write dirty frames back to disk. force.period - flush process wakes up automatically to write all buffers containing data belonging to the file system. This period is the guaranteed time after which an update to a protected file is written to disk.
output: Normal flush writes only dirty (modified) frames back to disk at regular intervals. Forced flush writes ALL file system buffers and provides a guaranteed maximum time for protected file updates to reach disk. Normal flush is for general performance, while forced flush ensures data integrity by guaranteeing write completion within a specified timeframe.

instruction: How do I set up keyboard input translation for an IBM 3151 terminal?
input:
Command: set-imap
Syntax: set-imap {item-ID{time.out}} {(options}
Description: Defines a keyboard input and/or terminal output translation table
Example: set-imap ibm3151 - Sets the keyboard translation to an ibm3151
output: Use 'set-imap ibm3151' to set up keyboard translation for an IBM 3151 terminal. This loads the translation table from the 'ibm3151' item in the keyboards file in the dm account, enabling proper interpretation of special key sequences like function keys and cursor movements for that terminal type.

instruction: Why is timeout adjustment important for keyboard translation?
input:
Command: set-imap
Parameter: time.out - Value expressed in milliseconds, after which an incomplete input sequence is aborted. Should be adjusted to the baud rate and possible special conditions, such as network delays, to detect sequences of characters properly.
Caution: If network conditions create large delays between characters, it might be necessary to set a larger time-out value.
output: Timeout adjustment is crucial because keyboard sequences (like ESC-[-A for cursor up) must be received within the timeout period to be recognized as single keystrokes. Network delays or slow connections can break sequences if timeout is too short. Set longer timeouts for network connections, but be aware this may cause individual keys like ESC to be misinterpreted as sequence starts.

instruction: What happens when I disable keyboard translation?
input:
Command: set-imap
Description: If there is no argument, the translation mechanism, if currently active, is disabled.
Example: set-imap - Disables the keyboard input translation
output: Running 'set-imap' without arguments disables the currently active keyboard translation mechanism. The terminal will revert to sending raw character codes without any translation, which means special key sequences may not work properly with applications expecting translated input.

instruction: How do I compile a modified keyboard translation item?
input:
Command: set-imap
Options: c - Compiles the item. This option must be used when the item is modified. The item is compiled into a binary item and stored in the dictionary of the keyboards file.
Example: set-imap att605 (c - Sets keyboard translation to att605, recompiling the item first
output: Use 'set-imap att605 (c' to recompile and load the att605 keyboard translation. The 'c' option is required whenever you modify a keyboard item - it compiles the item into binary format and stores it in the keyboards file dictionary. Without recompiling, changes to the source item won't take effect.

instruction: How would I set up character translation for port 5 using a numeric keyboard map?
input:
Command: set-iomap
Syntax: set-iomap port.number{,item-ID} ([i|o|ri|ro]
Description: Allows translatable input and output for each port on the system
Parameters: port.number - number of the port, item-ID - numeric user-defined keyboard item
output: Use 'set-iomap 5,12345 (i' to set up input character translation for port 5 using keyboard item 12345. The item-ID must be numeric and exist in the iomap-file in the dm account. Use (i) for input translation, (o) for output translation, or both. The keyboard item should contain ASCII translation mappings in the specified 34-attribute format.

instruction: What's the structure of an iomap keyboard item?
input:
Command: set-iomap
Keyboard item format: attr 0 - Item-ID, attr 1 - User comments, attr 2 to 33 - ASCII code of characters from 0 to 127 in ASCII hexadecimal format. Each attribute has exactly eight entries, each entry must be two characters.
Example: To translate character A to B: ASCII A is x'41' = d'65', ASCII B is x'42' = d'66', 65 mod 8 = 8 remainder 1, so B goes in attribute 10 at column 3 as '42'
output: An iomap keyboard item has 34 attributes: attr 0 (Item-ID), attr 1 (comments), and attrs 2-33 (character mappings). Each mapping attribute contains exactly 8 two-character hexadecimal entries representing ASCII codes 0-127. To map character A(65) to B(66): calculate 65Ã·8=8 remainder 1, so place '42' (hex for B) in attribute 10 (8+2) at position 3 (1Ã—2+1).

instruction: How do I remove input translation from a specific port?
input:
Command: set-iomap
Options: ri or ir - Removes an installed input keyboard, ro or or - Removes an installed output keyboard
output: Use 'set-iomap 5 (ri' to remove input keyboard translation from port 5, or 'set-iomap 5 (ro' to remove output translation. The 'ri' and 'ir' options are equivalent for removing input translation, and 'ro' and 'or' are equivalent for removing output translation.

instruction: How would I set a password for an OpenDB host connection?
input:
Command: set-opendb-password
Syntax: set-opendb-password hostname
Description: Sets or removes an encrypted password on an OpenDB host. Passwords are saved in attribute 3 of the hosts file.
Example: set-opendb-password myhost.sqlserver prompts for Password and Confirm
output: Use 'set-opendb-password myhost.sqlserver' to set a password for the OpenDB host. The system will prompt you to enter and confirm the password. The encrypted password is stored in attribute 3 of the hosts file. If the confirmation doesn't match, you'll be prompted to try again.

instruction: How do I remove a password from an OpenDB host?
input:
Command: set-opendb-password
To remove password: press RETURN at the Password: prompt and then press Y at the Remove Password? (Y/N) prompt.
Example: set-opendb-password myhost.sqlserver\nPassword:\nRemove Password? (Y/N)Y
output: To remove a password, run 'set-opendb-password hostname' and press RETURN (without entering a password) at the Password: prompt. The system will ask 'Remove Password? (Y/N)' - press Y to confirm removal. This will delete the encrypted password from attribute 3 of the hosts file.

instruction: What is the purpose of overflow ID signatures?
input:
Command: set-overflow-id
Syntax: set-overflow-id {(options}
Description: Toggles the overflow ID signature on and off.
Options: n - Enables the overflow ID signature, f - Disables the overflow ID signature
output: Overflow ID signatures are used for tracking file system overflow conditions. Use 'set-overflow-id (n' to enable or 'set-overflow-id (f' to disable these signatures. When enabled, the system marks overflow conditions which can be observed using commands like 'dump <fid> li' to examine file integrity and overflow status.

instruction: How can I observe the effects of overflow ID markings?
input:
Command: set-overflow-id
Example: set-overflow-id (n
create-file dum 1 1
observe fid
dump <fid> li
Then: set-overflow-id (f
delete-file dum
dump <fid> li
output: Enable overflow ID with 'set-overflow-id (n', create a test file, and use 'dump <fid> li' to observe the markings. Then disable with 'set-overflow-id (f', delete the file, and dump again to see that the overflow ID markings should remain unchanged, demonstrating how the signature system tracks overflow conditions.

instruction: How would I configure the local overflow cache settings for my current session?
input: The set-ovf-local command sets and displays the local overflow cache size. Syntax: set-ovf-local {ws.max}{,fs.max} {(options}. Parameters: ws.max sets the maximum workspace cache size, fs.max sets the maximum file space cache size. Options include: c (puts scrub pattern into local overflow frames), f (flushes all caches), g (copies current maximum cache settings into global default), s (suppresses display), x (disables local overflow scrubbing).
output: Use the set-ovf-local command to configure local overflow cache settings. To set specific cache sizes, specify ws.max for workspace cache and fs.max for file space cache. For example, 'set-ovf-local 100,300 (s' sets workspace cache to 100 and file space cache to 300 while suppressing display. Without parameters, it displays current cache status showing current and maximum values for both workspace and file space caches.

instruction: What happens when I run set-ovf-local without any parameters?
input: When specified without any options, the set-ovf-local command displays the cache status for the current line. The display shows a 2 by 2 grid of numbers. Example: set-ovf-local Private Overflow Cache Status: Current Max WS 2 20 File 10 30. This shows there are currently two workspace frames in the overflow cache with a maximum capacity of 20 frames, and 10 file space frames in the overflow cache with maximum capacity of 30 frames.
output: When run without parameters, set-ovf-local displays the current cache status in a 2x2 grid format showing Current and Max values for both WS (workspace) and File (file space) caches. For example, it might show WS has 2 current frames with max of 20, and File has 10 current frames with max of 30, indicating your current overflow cache utilization and limits.

instruction: Is it possible to make my overflow cache settings the global default for all new users?
input: The set-ovf-local command options include: g - Copies the current maximum cache settings into the global default. Whenever a new user logs on, they automatically acquire this default value. Note: The global defaults are automatically preset to a factory specified value upon reboot, so if a permanent global change is desired, the user should place the set-ovf-local command in the system-coldstart macro.
output: Yes, use the 'g' option with set-ovf-local to copy your current cache settings to the global default. For example, 'set-ovf-local 100,300 (sg' sets cache sizes and makes them the global default. However, these settings reset to factory defaults on reboot, so for permanent changes, add the set-ovf-local command to the system-coldstart macro in dm.

instruction: When should I flush my local overflow caches?
input: The set-ovf-local command option 'f' flushes all caches. All frames held within the current cache are released back to the main table. Note: This operation is automatically invoked when the maximum values are changed. The act of logging off the system automatically flushes all local overflow caches.
output: Flush local overflow caches using the 'f' option when you need to release all cached frames back to the main table immediately. This happens automatically when you change maximum values or log off the system. Use 'set-ovf-local (fs' to flush all caches manually, which can be useful for freeing up memory or ensuring fresh cache state.

instruction: How do I set aside frames as reserve overflow in case the overflow table runs out?
input: The set-ovf-reserve command in the DM account, sets aside a specific number of frames as the spare tank in the event that the overflow table runs out of frames. The default is 1024 or .5% of your available disk space (maxfid), whichever is greater. Syntax: set-ovf-reserve {(reserve.quantity)} {(options}. Parameter: reserve.quantity - Number of frames to set aside as reserve overflow. Options: q - Suppresses messages.
output: Use the set-ovf-reserve command in the DM account to set aside reserve overflow frames. Specify the number of frames in parentheses, like 'set-ovf-reserve (1024)' to reserve 1024 frames. The system defaults to 1024 frames or 0.5% of available disk space, whichever is greater. Add the 'q' option to suppress confirmation messages.

instruction: What output should I expect when changing the overflow reserve setting?
input: When the set-ovf-reserve command is run, the system displays both the old and new reserve values. Example: If your overflow reserve is set to 200, running the command 'set-ovf-reserve (1024)' produces the message 'Previous reserve: 200 New reserve: 1024'.
output: The set-ovf-reserve command displays both the previous and new reserve values when executed. For example, if you run 'set-ovf-reserve (1024)' and your current reserve was 200, you'll see: 'Previous reserve: 200 New reserve: 1024'. This confirms the change and shows you what the setting was before modification.

instruction: How would I configure communication settings for a specific serial port?
input: The set-port BASIC program displays or changes the communication speed and protocol for a specified port. Syntax: set-port [tty|port.number]{,baud,parity,stop.bits,word.length} {(options}. Parameters include: port.number (serial port number, -1 for current port), baud (110, 150, 300, 600, 1200, 2400, 4800, 9600, 19200), parity (n/0 for none, o/1 for odd, e/2 for even, m for mark, s for space), stop.bits (1 or 2), word.length (7 or 8). If no options are entered, current port settings display. If any option is entered, then all options must be entered.
output: Use set-port with the port number followed by communication parameters. For example, 'set-port 1,9600,n,1,8' configures port 1 with 9600 baud, no parity, 1 stop bit, and 8-bit word length. You must specify all parameters when making changes. Use 'set-port -1' to configure the current port, or just 'set-port' to display current settings without changes.

instruction: Why does set-port require all communication parameters when making changes?
input: The set-port command parameters: If no options are entered, the current port settings display. If any option is entered, then all options must be entered. Legal baud rates are: 110, 150, 300, 600, 1200, 2400, 4800, 9600, and 19200. Valid stop bits are 1 or 2. Valid word lengths are 7 or 8.
output: Set-port requires all communication parameters when making changes to ensure complete and consistent port configuration. This prevents partial configurations that could lead to communication errors. You must specify baud rate, parity, stop bits, and word length together, such as '9600,n,1,8' for 9600 baud, no parity, 1 stop bit, and 8-bit words, ensuring the port has a complete valid configuration.

instruction: Under what conditions would I need to use set-remote-user?
input: The set-remote-user BASIC program can be used to allow the local user to utilize a different user and/or password when connecting to a remote OSFI server which has been started with the 'a' option to force user/password authorization. When the client process attempts to open a file on a remote OSFI server which has been started with the 'a' option, the server refuses the request unless the passed user and password match a user and password present on that server. However, it is often not realistic for user names and/or passwords to be identical across different machines.
output: Use set-remote-user when connecting to remote OSFI servers that require authorization (started with 'a' option) and your local username/password differs from those on the remote server. This is common when user accounts aren't synchronized across machines. The command allows you to specify alternate credentials for remote connections, enabling file access when your local credentials don't match the remote server's user database.

instruction: How do I map my local user to a different remote user for server connections?
input: The third form allows the user to enter (or destroy if used with the k option) a mapping entry for the specified remote OSFI host. The program prompts for the remote user and password to be used on all future connections to that host. Example: set-remote-user macha Remote User: mark Remote Password: [blank]. This allows user mark access to open files on the macha server, with no password.
output: Use 'set-remote-user hostname' to create a mapping for a specific remote server. For example, 'set-remote-user macha' will prompt you for the remote username and password to use when connecting to the 'macha' server. You can specify a different username like 'mark' and leave the password blank if none is required. This mapping applies to all future connections to that host.

instruction: What's the difference between turning runaway autoquit on locally versus globally?
input: The set-runaway-autoquit command automatically terminates the specified process in the event of an overflow runaway condition. Parameters: n (turns feature on), f (turns feature off), l (local - applies to only the line from which command is executed), pib.num (applies to only the specified line). If neither pib.num or l option is specified, the command is applied to the global default. Examples: 'set-runaway-autoquit (n l' turns autoquit on for current line, 'set-runaway-autoquit (n' turns autoquit on for all lines with global limit.
output: Local (l option) applies runaway autoquit only to your current line/session, while global (no l option) sets the default for all lines system-wide. Use 'set-runaway-autoquit (n l' for local-only protection on your current session, or 'set-runaway-autoquit (n' to enable autoquit globally for all users. You can also target specific lines using the pib.num parameter instead of 'l'.

instruction: How would I establish a frame limit to prevent overflow runaway conditions?
input: The set-runaway-limit command establishes the maximum number of frames allowed before an overflow runaway condition occurs. If the number of frames acquired by the specified process reaches the specified limit, the system detects an overflow runaway condition and reports it. Parameters: limit (maximum number of frames, 0 for no maximum), options include pib (sets limit on specified port), d (specifies default runaway limit of 7000), l (sets limit locally for current line), r (removes limit on current line). If no parameters are provided, the current limit displays.
output: Use set-runaway-limit with a frame count to establish overflow protection. For example, 'set-runaway-limit 5000' sets a global limit of 5000 frames. Use 'set-runaway-limit (dl' to set the default limit (7000) locally, or 'set-runaway-limit (r' to remove local limits and use the global setting. Setting the limit to 0 removes the maximum entirely.

instruction: Why might a process hit the runaway limit and what should I do?
input: CAUTION: If a process creates a very large item, or select list, it may hit the specified limit. The command has to be aborted, the limit changed, and the command restarted. The default is normally set to a value which should suit most configurations. All overflow runaway conditions are logged to the errors file.
output: A process may hit the runaway limit when creating very large items or select lists that exceed the frame threshold. When this happens, you must abort the current command, increase the limit using set-runaway-limit with a higher value, then restart your command. The system logs all runaway conditions to the errors file for monitoring. The default limit of 7000 frames usually accommodates normal operations.

instruction: How do I create a pseudo tape device for backup operations?
input: The set-tapefile command creates a dynamically defined pseudo tape. The set-tapefile command allows pseudo tape devices to be dynamically created. This assignment of a tape device is temporary and can be overwritten by performing another set-tapefile command to the same virtual tape device. The tape file is now ready for use as a tape unit until the system is shut down. Commands such as t-dump, account-restore, file-save, and so on, function in customary fashion. Syntax: set-tapefile <path>. Parameter: path - A valid path on the host operating system without requiring surrounding quotation marks.
output: Use set-tapefile followed by a file path to create a pseudo tape device. For example, 'set-tapefile C:\ORDER ENTRY\LOS ANGELES\orders.d3p' creates a tape device pointing to that file location. The pseudo tape works with standard tape commands like t-dump, account-restore, and file-save until system shutdown. You can reassign the same virtual tape device by running set-tapefile again with a different path.

instruction: What's the purpose of the set-thousands and set-units commands?
input: The set-thousands command designates that a numeric expression of 1 is equal to 1000 units. The set-units command designates that a numeric expression of 1 is equal to 1 unit. Both commands have option 'u' to set the system default. Example with set-thousands: input of 3000 displays as 3, input of 5 displays as 5000. Example with set-units: input of 5 displays as 5 for both conversions (one-to-one correspondence).
output: Set-thousands and set-units control numeric scaling for unit conversions. Set-thousands makes 1 equal 1000 units, so 3000 displays as 3 and 5 becomes 5000. Set-units maintains one-to-one correspondence where 5 stays 5. These affect user exit conversions (u01b6 for input, u11b6 for output). Use the 'u' option with either command to make the setting a system default.

instruction: How do I terminate a shared printer process that's running with UNIX?
input: The shp-kill command terminates a D3 printer shared with UNIX and all the associated processes. Users who do not own the process and are not root, will not be able to kill the printer. Syntax: shp-kill number. Parameter: number - D3 printer number, as specified in the startshp command. This command executes 'sp-kill dprinter.number' and relies on log files created in /var/tmp/lppick by the startshp command. Example: shp-kill 0.
output: Use shp-kill followed by the printer number to terminate a shared D3 printer. For example, 'shp-kill 0' terminates printer 0. You must own the process or be root to kill it. The command automatically handles the D3 printer process, sends SIGTERM/SIGKILL to underlying processes, and terminates associated lppick filter processes. It only works with printers started by the startshp command.

instruction: What information does shp-status provide about shared printers?
input: The shp-status command displays status information about printers shared with UNIX, started by the startshp command. The display shows: VMname (virtual machine), Prt (printer number), Port, PID (process ID), Spooler command, and Status. Example output shows pick0 printer 0 on port 126 with PID 1763 using 'exec lp -onobanner' command with OK status. With the 't' option, trace information displays starting with newest entries.
output: Shp-status shows comprehensive printer status including virtual machine name, printer number, port, process ID, spooler command, and current status. It helps diagnose issues by showing whether printers are OK, if processes are dead, or if there are errors. The trace option ('shp-status (t') provides detailed activity logs with timestamps showing job starts, completions, and process events for troubleshooting printer problems.

instruction: Under what conditions should I run the shutdown command?
input: The shutdown BASIC program initiates an orderly system shutdown sequence, and should be executed before turning off or rebooting any D3 system. Critical files are checked for consistency, any user logged on is logged off, all process workspaces are released, all printers are stopped, all phantom jobs are logged off, and all updated memory frames are written to disk. The critical files checked include: mds,, dm,users, dm,, dm,pibs, dm,tcl-stack, dm,devices, dm,backgrounds. The macro user-shutdown on the dm account is executed if it exists.
output: Always run shutdown before turning off or rebooting any D3 system to ensure data integrity. The command performs critical cleanup: checks file consistency, logs off all users, releases workspaces, stops printers, terminates phantom jobs, and writes memory frames to disk. It also executes the user-shutdown macro if present for custom cleanup procedures. This prevents data corruption and ensures a clean system state.

instruction: How long can I make a process sleep using the sleep command?
input: The sleep command suspends further processing until the specified time expression is exhausted or reached. D3 supports the specification of milliseconds in expression. For example, to sleep for one and a half seconds, the user can use sleep 1.5. Parameter: expression - Specifies the number of seconds to suspend processing or the time to resume processing in the format hh:mm{:ss}. Hours are specified from 00 (midnight) to 23 (11:00 PM). Minutes and seconds are specified from 00 to 59. Examples: 'sleep 600' sleeps for 10 minutes, 'sleep 23:59:59' sleeps until one second before midnight.
output: The sleep command accepts seconds (including decimals like 1.5 for millisecond precision) or specific wake-up times in hh:mm or hh:mm:ss format. You can sleep for any duration in seconds (e.g., 'sleep 600' for 10 minutes) or until a specific time (e.g., 'sleep 23:59:59' to wake at 11:59:59 PM). Hours range from 00-23, minutes and seconds from 00-59.

instruction: How would I sort a previously saved list and update it in the file?
input: The sort-list BASIC program retrieves a previously saved list, sorts it, then rewrites it to the file from which it was retrieved. If the file reference is omitted, the process defaults to the pointer-file file. If the list name is omitted, the default list name, %user-ID, is used. Syntax: sort-list {dict|data} {file.reference} {list.name}. Example: get-list backorders, sort-list backorders - sorts the list 'backorders' found in the pointer-file file.
output: Use sort-list with the list name to sort and update a saved list. For example, first 'get-list backorders' then 'sort-list backorders' to sort the backorders list in the pointer-file. You can specify dict/data, file reference, and list name. Without parameters, it sorts the default list (%user-ID) in the pointer-file. The sorted list overwrites the original saved list.

instruction: What does the sortc command display and how can I customize the output?
input: The sortc BASIC program invokes the sort-label command to produce a columnar display of the item-IDs in the specified file, in the order of appearance in the file. Any valid selection criteria may be passed through to AQL for processing. The default is a four column display. If a numeric option is entered, then that number of columns, up to six, display. Syntax: sortc file.reference {sellist} {heading "heading text"} {(n}.
output: Sortc displays item-IDs in columnar format (default 4 columns, up to 6 with numeric option). For example, 'sortc messages with a0 > "0]" and with a0 < "2]" (n)' shows items from the messages file with selection criteria in the default format. You can add custom headings with 'heading "text"' and specify column count with a numeric parameter. It processes AQL selection criteria and shows items in file appearance order.

instruction: How do I configure spooler output settings for my current process?
input:
The sp-assign command displays, changes, or resets the current spooler output assignment options for the current process/user. An sp-assign command with no options closes any currently open files assigned by the current process and resets the assignment to the default state. The default assignment is: output to printer, normal spooler entry (meaning, not a hold file), one copy, form queue 0, close files at end of process, queue job for output immediately upon closing.

Syntax: sp-assign {options}
output: Use the sp-assign command to configure spooler output settings for your current process. The command syntax is `sp-assign {options}`. When used without options, it resets to default settings: output to printer, normal spooler entry, one copy, form queue 0, close files at end of process, and queue job for output immediately upon closing. You can modify these defaults using various options like specifying number of copies, form queue numbers, or output destinations.

instruction: What happens when I run sp-assign without any parameters?
input: The sp-assign command displays, changes, or resets the current spooler output assignment options for the current process/user. An sp-assign command with no options closes any currently open files assigned by the current process and resets the assignment to the default state. The default assignment is: output to printer, normal spooler entry (meaning, not a hold file), one copy, form queue 0, close files at end of process, queue job for output immediately upon closing.
output: When you run sp-assign without any parameters, it closes any currently open files assigned by the current process and resets the assignment to the default state. The default assignment includes: output to printer, normal spooler entry (not a hold file), one copy, form queue 0, close files at end of process, and queue job for output immediately upon closing.

instruction: Show me how to check current spooler assignment settings with an example
input:
Example: sp-assign hs ?
Line#   Status   Copies   Form#   Device
39      hs       1        0       dp.lzr

Line# - Port number to which this terminal is attached.
Status - Assignment options set by sp-assign.
Copies - Number of copies to print.
Form# - Form queue numbers.
Device - Printer device name.
output:
To check current spooler assignment settings, use `sp-assign` with the `?` option. For example, `sp-assign hs ?` displays:
```
Line#   Status   Copies   Form#   Device
39      hs       1        0       dp.lzr
```
This shows Line# (port number), Status (assignment options), Copies (number to print), Form# (form queue numbers), and Device (printer device name).

instruction: Is it possible to send output to a hold file instead of printing immediately?
input:
Parameter: h - Spools output to a hold file.
i - Spools output to the printer immediately.
p - Assigns output to the printer. This is the default.
output: Yes, you can send output to a hold file instead of printing immediately by using the `h` option with sp-assign. The `h` parameter spools output to a hold file, while `i` spools output to the printer immediately, and `p` assigns output to the printer (which is the default behavior).

instruction: How would I specify multiple copies and a specific form queue in one command?
input:
Parameter: number.copies - (Integer number in the range 1-125.) Indicates the number of copies (default = one).
f number - Specifies the output queue into which a print file will be inserted. The number must be between 0 and 2047, inclusive. The default output queue is 0.

Example: sp-assign 13 f11 ?
Line#   Status   Copies   Form#   Device
39      9        13       11      dp.lzrii
output: To specify multiple copies and a specific form queue in one command, use the syntax `sp-assign [number.copies] f[queue.number]`. For example, `sp-assign 13 f11` sets 13 copies and form queue 11. The example shows the result: Line# 39, Status 9, Copies 13, Form# 11, Device dp.lzrii.

instruction: What does the sp-close command accomplish?
input:
The sp-close command closes all current spooler entries previously opened by the current line with an sp-open command or an o option in conjunction with an sp-assign command.

Syntax: sp-close

Example: sp-close
[1140] your open files were closed.
output: The sp-close command closes all current spooler entries that were previously opened by the current line using either an sp-open command or the 'o' option with an sp-assign command. When executed, it displays a confirmation message like '[1140] your open files were closed.'

instruction: How do I access and edit existing spooler entries?
output: Use the sp-edit command to access and edit existing spooler entries. The syntax is `sp-edit {options}`. When used without options, it retrieves all available (unspooled) entries generated from the current user-ID for processing. Note that only files in hold status are available for editing.

instruction: Can I delete specific print files using sp-edit, and if so, how?
input:
Parameter: d - Deletes print files, when used in conjunction with a print file number or a range of print file numbers. Note: Must be used with the m option.

file.number{-number} - Designates print file, or a range of print files, if available, and must be within the range of 1 through 31,999, inclusive.

Example: sp-edit nd1-10 - Obtains print jobs 1 through 10, and deletes them.
output: Yes, you can delete specific print files using sp-edit with the 'd' option combined with the 'm' option. Specify the file number or range (1-31,999). For example, `sp-edit nd1-10` obtains print jobs 1 through 10 and deletes them. The 'd' option must always be used with the 'm' option.

instruction: Show me an example of editing spooler entries for a specific user and form queue
input:
Parameter: 'user.ID' - On D3, spooler entries are stored under the user-ID of who generated them. This accesses the spooler entries created by the specified user-ID. Single quotation marks are required around the user-ID.

f number{-number} - Edits jobs for a specific form queue, or a range of form queues, and must be an integer number in the range of 0 to 1023.

Example: sp-edit 'pr' f4 p ms - If the current user-ID has sys2 privileges, this spools all available print files created by the pr user-ID in output queue 4 to the printer, and ends sp-edit.
output: To edit spooler entries for a specific user and form queue, use the syntax with user-ID in quotes and the f option. For example: `sp-edit 'pr' f4 p ms` - This command (requiring sys2 privileges) spools all available print files created by the 'pr' user-ID in output queue 4 to the printer and ends sp-edit. The user-ID must be enclosed in single quotation marks.

instruction: When would I use the sp-kill command and what are its main functions?
input:
The sp-kill command stops spooler entry output or removes printers and shared printers. This command provides the following functions: Aborts the currently active print jobs immediately. Dequeues print files on the optionally specified printer. Removes printers from the spooler system.

If no options are specified, sp-kill aborts the current print job on printer 0 (zero). Unless the user-ID has sys2 privileges, only print files generated by the current user-ID invoking the sp-kill can be aborted.
output: Use the sp-kill command to stop spooler entry output or remove printers. Its main functions include: aborting currently active print jobs immediately, dequeuing print files on specified printers, and removing printers from the spooler system. Without options, it aborts the current print job on printer 0. Note that unless you have sys2 privileges, you can only abort print files generated by your own user-ID.

instruction: How do I kill print jobs on multiple printers at once?
input:
Parameter: printer.number{-printer.number} - Aborts jobs on a given printer number, or a range of printer numbers, between 0 and the maximum printer number.

b - All entries. When used with the d option, this kills all printers. When used without any other option, this aborts all active printers.

Example: sp-kill 3-5 - kills the print files going to printers 3, 4, and 5.
sp-kill b - Kills all print files going to all printers.
output: To kill print jobs on multiple printers, you can specify a range using `printer.number-printer.number` or use the 'b' option for all printers. For example: `sp-kill 3-5` kills print files going to printers 3, 4, and 5, while `sp-kill b` kills all print files going to all printers. The range must be between 0 and the maximum printer number.

instruction: What information does sp-status display about the spooler system?
input:
The sp-status command displays the status of all spooler-controlled devices. If no options are specified, the status of the spooler and all allocated printers displays.

Example: sp-status
The spooler is inactive.
Printer # 0 is serial, inactive, and on line.
The printer is running on line 13.
Assigned output queues: 0.
The number of inter-job pages to eject is 1.
output: The sp-status command displays comprehensive information about spooler-controlled devices including: spooler status (active/inactive), printer numbers and their status (serial, active/inactive, online status), which line each printer is running on, assigned output queues, and the number of inter-job pages to eject. For example, it might show 'The spooler is inactive. Printer # 0 is serial, inactive, and on line.'

instruction: How would I retrieve reports from magnetic tape and send them to the spooler?
output: Use the sp-tapeout command to retrieve reports from magnetic tape and send them to the spooler. The syntax is `sp-tapeout {options}`. The command reads the file at the current tape location and directs output to the spooler, which then redirects according to your current sp-assign settings. For example, simply running `sp-tapeout` spools the file to the destination specified by your current sp-assign command.

instruction: Is there a way to convert EBCDIC format to ASCII when reading from tape?
input:
Parameter: a - Converts EBCDIC format to ASCII format.
u - Converts all lowercase characters to uppercase.
l - Treats each tape record as a line, if the tape record length is less than 140.

Example: sp-tapeout ua - Reads the file (at the current location of the tape), converts the data from EBCDIC to ASCII, converts all characters to uppercase, and spools the file to the destination specified by the user's sp-assign command.
output: Yes, you can convert EBCDIC format to ASCII when reading from tape using the 'a' option with sp-tapeout. For example, `sp-tapeout ua` reads the file at the current tape location, converts the data from EBCDIC to ASCII, converts all characters to uppercase, and spools the file to the destination specified by your sp-assign command.

instruction: How do I create a sample select-list from a file for testing purposes?
input:
The ssample command creates and sorts a temporary select-list of the first n items in a file that match the specified criteria. This command is useful when testing a small number of items. For example, testing 100 items in a file rather than processing all 10,000 items.

Syntax: ssample [DICT] filename [item-list] [selection] [sort-keys] [output] (n)
output: Use the ssample command to create a sample select-list for testing. The syntax is `ssample [DICT] filename [item-list] [selection] [sort-keys] [output] (n)` where 'n' is the number of items to sample. This creates and sorts a temporary select-list of the first n items that match your criteria, which is useful for testing a small subset (like 100 items) instead of processing an entire large file (like 10,000 items).

instruction: Show me an example of using ssample with selection criteria and sorting
input:
Example: The following example creates a select-list containing the first four items in the ORDERS file whose sale date is January 15, 2018:

>SSAMPLE ORDERS WITH DATE = "01/15/18" (4)
4 ITEMS SELECTED.

If you list these items with the list command, they appear in sorted order:

>LIST ORDERS
0134
0156
0179
0234

4 ITEMS LISTED.
output: Here's an example using ssample with selection criteria: `SSAMPLE ORDERS WITH DATE = "01/15/18" (4)` creates a select-list containing the first four items in the ORDERS file whose sale date is January 15, 2018. The command returns '4 ITEMS SELECTED.' When you subsequently use `LIST ORDERS`, the items appear in sorted order: 0134, 0156, 0179, 0234, showing '4 ITEMS LISTED.'

instruction: What does the startlog command do and when should I use it?
input:
The startlog command activates the transaction logging subsystem. All items in files with a dl-type are automatically logged to the attached magnetic media on each add, change, or delete to the item.

Before invoking this command, a tape device must already be attached to the current port because the transaction logger steals the tape device.
output: The startlog command activates the transaction logging subsystem, which automatically logs all items in files with a dl-type to attached magnetic media whenever you add, change, or delete items. Use this when you need to maintain a transaction log for data recovery purposes. Important: you must attach a tape device to the current port before invoking this command, as the transaction logger takes control of the tape device.

instruction: How would I restart the transaction logger with new backup media?
input:
Parameter: u - Restarts the transaction logger and asks for new backup media. Backup media can only be specified after a system restore with this option. If no backup media has been specified, startlog prompts for one.

Syntax: startlog {{port.number}{,wait.time}} {(options)}
output: To restart the transaction logger with new backup media, use the 'u' option: `startlog (u)`. This option restarts the transaction logger and prompts for new backup media. Note that backup media can only be specified after a system restore when using this option. If no backup media has been previously specified, startlog will prompt you to specify one.

instruction: Can I start multiple printers simultaneously, and what's the syntax?
output: Yes, the startptr command can activate and initialize up to 2048 printers (depending on hardware configuration). The syntax is `startptr number{,queue, eject.pages, type/address,{a} {(options)}}` or `startptr number, (q1{,q2{,q3}}), eject.pages, type/address, {a} {(options)}`. If a printer is already active, startptr has no effect on that printer.

instruction: Show me how to start a printer with multiple form queues using an example
input:
Example: startptr 9,(98,99),1,s19 - Starts printer 9 on form queues 98 and 99, skipping 1 page between jobs, on serial port 19.
startptr 1,(3,4,5),1,s11 - Starts printer 1 on form queues 3, 4 and 5, skipping 1 page between jobs, on serial port 11.
output: To start a printer with multiple form queues, specify the queues in parentheses separated by commas. For example: `startptr 9,(98,99),1,s19` starts printer 9 on form queues 98 and 99, skipping 1 page between jobs, on serial port 19. Another example: `startptr 1,(3,4,5),1,s11` starts printer 1 on form queues 3, 4, and 5, skipping 1 page between jobs, on serial port 11.

instruction: Under what conditions would I use the startshp command instead of startptr?
input:
The startshp command starts a shared printer under UNIX. The output of the D3 printer process is routed to the UNIX spooler. This command combines the startptr command and the necessary assignfq command.

For Windows: Not Supported
output: Use the startshp command instead of startptr when you need to start a shared printer under UNIX, where the D3 printer process output is routed to the UNIX spooler. The startshp command combines both the startptr command and the necessary assignfq command functionality. Note that this command is not supported on Windows systems.

instruction: How do I move a file from another account into my current account?
input:
The steal-file BASIC program is the only valid way to move a file from another account into the current account. This physically moves a file to the current master dictionary from another master dictionary. steal-file prompts for the account name and requires sys2 privileges.

Syntax: steal-file file.reference
from account: account.name

Example: steal-file goods
from account:victims
output: Use the steal-file command to move a file from another account into your current account. The syntax is `steal-file file.reference` followed by `from account: account.name`. For example: `steal-file goods from account:victims`. This command requires sys2 privileges and physically moves the file to your current master dictionary. After stealing a file, the former owner loses all access to it.

instruction: What happens to the original owner after I steal their file?
input:
After stealing a file, the former owner has no reference to it, not even visitation rights. He or she can get visitation rights by building a Q-pointer to where the file moved, or by referencing the path name.

steal-file prompts for the account name and requires sys2 privileges. It also requires that the user invoking steal-file is not protected against updating the file at any level, master dictionary, file level dictionary, or data file level.
output: After you steal a file, the original owner loses all access to it, including visitation rights. They can only regain access by building a Q-pointer to the file's new location or by referencing the path name. The steal-file operation requires sys2 privileges and that you're not protected against updating the file at any level (master dictionary, file level dictionary, or data file level).

instruction: How do I stop a specific printer while allowing it to finish its current job?
input:
The stopptr command stops the specified printer at the end of the current print job. If the printer is inactive, it stops immediately. If it is active, it stops at the end of the current print file. If the current print file is specified to print multiple copies, the printer stops after the completion of the current copy. Sys2 privileges are required to use stopptr.

Syntax: stopptr {options}
output: Use the stopptr command to stop a specific printer while allowing it to finish its current job. The syntax is `stopptr {options}`. The printer stops at the end of the current print job - if inactive, it stops immediately; if active, it completes the current print file. For multiple copy jobs, it stops after completing the current copy. Note that sys2 privileges are required to use this command.

instruction: Is there a way to wait until a printer has completely stopped before continuing?
input:
Parameter: w - Waits until the printer has completed printing any print file and is inactive. This option can be used, for example, when the stopptr command is issued from a macro, followed by a startptr command. This ensures that the printer is stopped before startptr is executed.

Example: stopptr 1w - Sets printer #1 to stop, then waits for printer #1 to become inactive before returning to TCL.
output: Yes, use the 'w' option with stopptr to wait until the printer has completely stopped. For example: `stopptr 1w` sets printer #1 to stop, then waits for it to become inactive before returning to TCL. This is particularly useful in macros where you need to ensure a printer is fully stopped before executing a subsequent startptr command.

instruction: How do I perform hexadecimal subtraction using system commands?
input:
The subx command subtracts the second hexadecimal number provided from the first hexadecimal number provided and displays the result as a hexadecimal number.

Syntax: subx hex.number hex.number

Example: subx 400 8A376
output: Use the subx command to perform hexadecimal subtraction. The syntax is `subx hex.number hex.number` where the second number is subtracted from the first number. The result is displayed as a hexadecimal number. For example: `subx 400 8A` subtracts 8A from 400 and displays the hexadecimal result.

instruction: What kind of system information does the syschk command monitor?
input:
The syschk BASIC program checks a system running under UNIX to detect abnormal situations. For Windows: Not Supported

The UNIX parameters are obtained through a variety of more or less UNIX-dependent commands. Often, on a given UNIX version, there might be several ways of obtaining the information.
output: The syschk command monitors various UNIX system parameters to detect abnormal situations, including CPU usage, swap space usage, process monitoring, and file system status. It obtains information through various UNIX-dependent commands like sar, ps, and others. Note that syschk is not supported on Windows systems and results may vary between different UNIX versions due to different ways of obtaining system information.

instruction: Show me how to set up syschk to monitor system resources with specific thresholds
input:
Example 1: This example starts a phantom process to check the system every 30 minutes for a CPU system usage above 10%, a swap usage above 60% and a process runaway limit of 10%. In case of anomaly, a message is sent to the UNIX terminal /dev/tty0, D3 user bob if he is logged on, Line 0, whether it is logged on or not. A short message is also logged in the errors file.

syschk sampling=00:30:00 syscpu=10% notify=/dev/tty0,bob,!0 swapusg=60% proccpu=10% log
output: To set up syschk with specific monitoring thresholds, use this example: `syschk sampling=00:30:00 syscpu=10% notify=/dev/tty0,bob,!0 swapusg=60% proccpu=10% log`. This starts a phantom process that checks every 30 minutes for: CPU system usage above 10%, swap usage above 60%, and process runaway limit of 10%. Anomaly messages are sent to UNIX terminal /dev/tty0, D3 user 'bob' if logged on, and Line 0 regardless of login status, with a short message also logged in the errors file.

instruction: What system configuration details does the sysid command reveal?
input:
The sysid BASIC program displays system configuration, options, and features. The sysid command displays various information about the current platform including the host system, processor type, and implementation. Any host O/S options available from D3 are shown under System Options.

Example: sysid
Host system     : Windows Server
processor type  : Intel or compatible
Implementation  : D3 Windows
System ID       : 12345678

System Options:
I/O Subsystem Support

Features         Status     Features       Status
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
FlashConnect     Available   OpenDB        Available
Hot-Backup       Available   WebSphere MQ  Available
Oracle Gateway   Available
output: The sysid command reveals comprehensive system configuration details including: host system type, processor type, D3 implementation version, system ID, available system options (like I/O Subsystem Support), and D3 features with their availability status. For example, it might show 'Host system: Windows Server, processor type: Intel or compatible, Implementation: D3 Windows' along with a table showing features like FlashConnect, OpenDB, Hot-Backup, WebSphere MQ, and Oracle Gateway with their availability status.

instruction: How do I switch between multiple attached tape devices?
input:
The t-act command selects a previously attached tape device as the currently active device to read and write to. D3 releases not only can have many users using many tapes simultaneously, a single user can have multiple tapes. This command allows switching between tapes.

Syntax: t-act device.num

Parameter: device.num - Device to make active.
output: Use the t-act command to switch between multiple attached tape devices. The syntax is `t-act device.num` where device.num is the device number you want to make active. This allows you to switch between different tape devices that you have attached, as D3 supports multiple users with multiple tapes simultaneously, and even a single user can work with multiple tapes.

instruction: Can you demonstrate switching between tape devices with a practical example?
input:
Example: set-device 1
set-device 2
t-dump md
t-act 2
t-dump md
t-act 1
t-dump bp
t-act 2
t-dump bp
t-det
output:
Here's a practical example of switching between tape devices: 
1. `set-device 1` and `set-device 2` - attach two tape devices
2. `t-dump md` - dump master dictionary to device 1 (current active)
3. `t-act 2` - switch to device 2
4. `t-dump md` - dump master dictionary to device 2
5. `t-act 1` - switch back to device 1
6. `t-dump bp` - dump business processes to device 1
7. `t-act 2` - switch to device 2
8. `t-dump bp` - dump business processes to device 2
9. `t-det` - detach the current device

This demonstrates how to work with multiple tapes for different backup operations.

instruction: How can I configure a continuous loop so that tape drives 2 and 3 keep writing without ever asking for the next reel?
output: Run âžœ  t-cascade 2,3,2  â€” this links drive 2 to 3 and drive 3 back to 2, forming a loop. Because the chain is circular, the operating system simply keeps using the forward link and never issues a reel-change prompt, so it is up to the operator to mount reels correctly.

instruction: Under what circumstances will t-cascade still stop and ask for a new reel even though devices are cascaded?
input:
Syntax: t-cascade â€¦
Description: In a simple chain the system moves from the current drive to the next until the last device is full; once the last drive in the chain reaches end-of-tape it reverts to prompting for the next reel.
output: If you set up a **chain** (e.g. t-cascade 2,3,4,5) rather than a loop, the system writes through each drive only once. After the final drive in that chain fills, there is no further link, so the process reverts to normal behaviour and asks the operator to mount the next reel.

instruction: Explain why all tape drives must share the same block size (or be auto-switchable) when I use t-cascade.
input: Description excerpt: â€œAll tape drives involved in the cascade must be at the same block size or be able to change to the starting driveâ€™s block size automatically for the cascade to succeed.
output: During a cascade every subsequent drive receives data that was framed for the first driveâ€™s block size. If a later drive cannot accept that block length, writes will fail and the cascade breaks. Requiring identical (or auto-negotiated) block sizes guarantees that each linked device can accept the incoming data stream without errors.

instruction: I need to copy only the first account from a multi-account save on tape. How would I do that with t-copy?
output: Attach both devices, then execute âžœ  t-copy 0 2 (3  â€” the â€œ(3 option limits the copy to the first three file segments, which correspond to the first account in a save-format tape.

instruction: Is it possible to run t-copy without specifying (file.count, and what happens if I omit it?
output: Yes. If you do not supply (file.count, t-copy defaults to one file segment. For instance â€˜t-copy 0 2â€™ copies from the current block on device 0 up to the first EOF mark onto device 2.

instruction: Why must both the source and destination devices already be attached before I issue t-copy?
input: Parameter note: â€œBoth source and destination devices must be attached to the current process.
output: t-copy operates entirely within the current D3 process; the command has no built-in mechanism to attach devices on-the-fly. If either device is unattached, the process cannot read from or write to it, and the copy fails. Attaching ahead of time ensures both channels are open and correctly configured.

instruction: Give me a one-liner that dumps only invoices dated on or before 1 Jan 2005, and labels the tape accordingly.
input:
Syntax: t-dump file.reference {selection.criteria} {heading "text"}
Example: t-dump invoices with date <= "1/1/05" heading "Pre-2005 archived invoices"
output: t-dump invoices with date <= "1/1/05" heading "Pre-2005 archived invoices"

instruction: Why does t-dump prompt for another reel, and what choices do I have when it does?
input: Description excerpt: â€œIn multireel operations the process detects end of media and prompts: insert next reel â€” press c to continue or q to quit.
output:
When the current reel reaches physical end-of-media, t-dump cannot continue writing. It pauses and issues the prompt. At that point you may:
â€¢ Mount a new reel and type **c** to carry on dumping, or
â€¢ Type **q** to abandon the dump and return to TCL.

instruction: Explain the purpose of the t-dump â€˜aâ€™ option and when I should use it.
input: Parameter excerpt: â€˜a â€“ makes backward-compatible tapes.â€™
output: Use the **(a** option when the target system is an older release that expects the earlier tape label format. It forces t-dump to write a backward-compatible header so the tape is readable by legacy Pick/D3 environments.

instruction: What does t-eod actually do to the tape device?
input:
Description: â€œThe t-eod command moves a tape forward to the end of the recorded data.â€
Example output shows END OF RECORDED DATA.
output: t-eod issues consecutive reads until it encounters two successive tape file marks (the logical end-of-data), positioning the device just beyond the last written block. The drive is now ready for appending new files without overwriting existing data.

instruction: I ran t-eod and saw â€œBLOCK SIZE: 16896   [92] END OF RECORDED DATA â€“ 3 FILE(S)â€. What do those numbers mean?
input: Example output: BLOCK SIZE: 16896  â€¦ END OF RECORDED DATA â€“ 3 FILE(S)
output:
â€¢ 16896 = the block length (bytes) of the data already on the tape.
â€¢ 3 FILE(S) = three file marks (three logical files) were crossed before reaching the physical end-of-data.

instruction: Can t-eod be used on any Pick-formatted media, or only on streaming cartridge tape?
input: Description states it simply moves the tape to end of recorded data; no media restrictions are listed.
output: t-eod is generic: it works on whatever Pick-formatted medium is attached (SCT, DAT, Â½-inch, pseudo-floppy, etc.) because it relies only on reading blocks until it sees end-of-file markers.

instruction: How would I clear existing links on tape device 4 so it starts prompting again at end-of-tape?
output: Execute âžœ  t-link 4 (c  â€” the (c option removes any cascade/loop information for device 4, restoring normal EOT prompting.

instruction: Is there any functional difference between t-link and t-cascade?
input: Description snippet (identical wording in both commands).
output: No. t-link is an alias of t-cascade; both commands update the tape-link table in the same way. The choice is stylistic.

instruction: Why is block-size consistency still important when I use t-link to chain drives?
input: Description: â€œAll tape drives involved â€¦ must be at the same block size.â€
output: Because data streaming continues unchanged from one drive to the next, any mismatch in block length would make the receiving drive reject or mis-interpret the blocks. Ensuring identical (or auto-adjustable) block sizes prevents write errors and guarantees data integrity across the chain.

instruction: After a multi-reel backup I have an unlabeled tape positioned at the correct file mark. How do I restore it without a label?
input:
Syntax: t-load â€¦ (options
Description: If the tape is unlabeled t-load backspaces one block but you must have set the correct block size via t-att.
output: Use t-att to set the block size first, then issue t-load with no selection criteria. Because the tape lacks a label, t-load recognises that on its first read, back-spaces, and proceeds to load the data as long as the block size is correctly set.

instruction: What does the (o option do in t-load and when should I use it?
input: Parameter: o â€” overwrites existing items when duplicate IDs exist.
output: Include (o whenever you expect some of the item-IDs already exist in the target file and you want the tape copy to replace them. Without (o, duplicates raise error 223 and the items are skipped unless you also use (m to suppress that message.

instruction: If I only want to verify what would be restored without changing the file system, can t-load help?
input: Parameter: v â€” reads items but does not write them.
output: Yes. Run t-load â€¦ (v to read every record into memory, ensuring the tape and selection criteria are correct, while leaving the on-disk file untouched. Combine with (o to preview duplicate handling (items are still not written when v is present).

instruction: How do I display blocks 100-120 on the attached tape in hex?
input:
Syntax: t-read {options}
Parameter: block.number{-block.number} plus x to display in hexadecimal.
output: t-read 100-120 (x    â€” reads that block range and prints each block in hexadecimal format.

instruction: Why does t-read pause after each page, and how can I suppress that behaviour?
input: Parameter: n â€” no pause.
output: By default the command stops at the end of every terminal page so you can inspect the output. Add the (n option (or just n in the option list) to disable paging and let the dump scroll continuously.

instruction: Can t-read convert an EBCDIC-labelled tape to ASCII on-the-fly?
input: Parameter: a â€” converts EBCDIC to ASCII.
output: Yes. Use the a option: e.g. t-read (a  â€” every block is translated from EBCDIC before display or spooling.

instruction: I have several floppy drives and want to attach the 3.5-inch low-density unit without looking up its number. How?
input:
Syntax: t-select {device.num}|{keyword} {(options}
Example list shows â€˜t-select 720kâ€™.

instruction: Whatâ€™s the main purpose of using the touch command in a D3 system?
input:
The touch BASIC program reads and rewrites all items, without changing them, in either specified files or in all files in specified accounts.
The main usage of this command is to force the transaction logger to enqueue for logging all items in files or in accounts, to synchronize databases across a network.
output: The primary purpose of the touch command is to force the transaction logger to enqueue all items from specified files or accounts. This helps synchronize distributed databases by ensuring that every item is logged without modifying its content.

instruction: When should I prefer using the 'l' option with the touch command?
input:
options:
l - Log only. This option bypasses the update mechanism, but places all items into the transaction log queue. This makes the touch command much faster and less abusive so long as a true update is not required.
output: Use the 'l' option when you only need to enqueue items for logging without actually updating them. This makes the process faster and avoids heavy I/O, which is ideal if youâ€™re just aiming to synchronize logs without rewriting data.

instruction: How does the trap command help in handling UNIX signals within D3?
input:
The trap BASIC program allows a TCL command (signal handler) to be executed when receiving a specific signal.
By default, signal handlers are set for the whole virtual machine. When it is preferable to differentiate the signal handlers depending on the user or account, a FlashBASIC program, a Proc, or an environ script must be provided to execute commands selectively.
output: The trap command enables you to set up signal handlers in D3, allowing TCL commands to be triggered when certain UNIX signals are received. It helps handle process-level events like alarms, timeouts, or power failures gracefully within the system.

trap pib 49 tdmon display @(-13)tandem entered@(-14)
This will cause the message to be displayed in reverse video when the tandem on signal is received.

instruction: What happens if 15 TCL levels are already pushed when a signal is received?
input: Note: The signal handler is executed by pushing a level. If 15 TCL levels are pushed when the signal occurs, it is not processed.
output: If the process has already reached 15 TCL levels, additional signals will be ignored and not processed, as no more levels can be pushed for trap handlers to execute.

instruction: Give an example of how to reset all signal handlers back to their default state.

output: The 'pwr' signal indicates a power-off event. It's critical to ensure proper coordination between the system-level handler (in inittab) and the D3 trap handler to prevent inconsistency or improper shutdowns during power failures.

instruction: How can I check the system configuration and status of system locks in D3?

Parameters: 'user-ID' - Outputs status only for users of the specified user-ID. {port.number{-port.number}} - Outputs the status for the given port, or a range of ports. Options include: l - Suppresses display of lock status, n - No pause, p - Directs output to system printer, s - Suppresses display of sp-status, w - Suppresses display of where output, z - Displays where status for all lines including inactive lines.

instruction: What system information does the what command display?
input:
Command: what
Syntax: what {port.number{-port.number}} {'user-ID'} {(options)}
Description: The what command displays the system configuration and the status of system locks, specified lines, spooler, and printers.
System configuration information displays: memory - Amount of memory allocated to the D3 virtual machine in kilobytes, pibs - Number of process identification blocks, pcb0 - FID for the PCB for line 0, sysbase/mod - Base FID and modulo of the master dictionary's file, maxfid - Last addressable FID on the system, available - Number of frames available in overflow, dfsize - Number of bytes available per data frame.
output:
The what command displays comprehensive system configuration information including:

- memory: Amount of memory allocated to the D3 virtual machine (in kilobytes)
- pibs: Number of process identification blocks (includes communication lines for terminals, serial printers, spooler, phantom processes, and scheduler)
- pcb0: FID for the PCB for line 0
- sysbase/mod: Base FID and modulo of the master dictionary's (system) file
- maxfid: Last addressable FID on the system
- available: Number of frames available in overflow
- dfsize: Number of bytes available per data frame (actual frame sizes: dfsize 1000 = 1024 bytes, 2000 = 2048 bytes, 4000 = 4096 bytes)

Additionally, it uses the where command to display current line status, list-locks command for system lock table, and sp-status command for spooler and printer status.

instruction: Can I limit the what command output to specific users or ports?
input:
Command: what
Syntax: what {port.number{-port.number}} {'user-ID'} {(options)}
Description: The what command displays the system configuration and the status of system locks, specified lines, spooler, and printers.
Parameters: 'user-ID' - Outputs status only for users of the specified user-ID. {port.number{-port.number}} - Outputs the status for the given port, or a range of ports.
Examples: what 'dm' - outputs all items indicated, but limits where output only to those on the dm account. what 13-22 - outputs all items indicated, but limits where output only to lines 13 through 22.
output:
Yes, you can limit the what command output in several ways:

1. By user-ID: Use what 'user-ID' to show status only for a specific user. For example: what 'dm' limits the where output to only those on the dm account.

2. By port number: Use what port.number for a single port, or what port.number-port.number for a range. For example: what 13-22 limits the where output to only lines 13 through 22.

These filters help you focus on specific users or port ranges while still displaying the complete system configuration information.

instruction: How do I check the current execution status of all processes logged on to the system?

Basic syntax: where {port.number{-port.number}} {user-ID} {(options)}

You can filter the output by:
- user-ID: Show status for a specific user only (quotation marks are optional in D3)
- account: Show status for processes using a specified account name
- port.number or range: Show status for specific ports or port ranges

The command displays execution status information for processes, helping you monitor system activity and process states.

instruction: What options are available with the where command for customizing the output?
output:

- a: Displays a character next to PIBs information indicating license consumption type

- n: No pause - suppresses the pause at the end of the page on the terminal
- o: When used with 'a' option, shows information only for PIBs with specified settings
- p: Directs output to the system printer via the spooler
- u: Returns the user tally under the Stat column heading
- z: Displays where status for all ports, including inactive ports (those not currently logged on)

Note: When using the 'a' option, an asterisk is not displayed next to the port that issued the command.

instruction: Show me examples of using the where command with different filters

   where 13-22
   Shows status of port numbers 13 through 22

3. Show all ports:
   where (z
   Shows status of all port numbers, including inactive ones

4. Show license information:
   where (a
   Displays a report showing direct connected lines using Connection Pool licenses, with characters indicating license consumption types

These examples demonstrate how to focus on specific users, port ranges, or get comprehensive system-wide process status information.

instruction: How do I copy items between D3 and the Windows file system?
output:
Use the wincopy command to transfer items between D3 and the Windows file system.

Syntax: WINCOPY {filename} {item.list} {(options)} TO:{(filename} {item.list}

The wincopy command is a modified version of the copy command that:
- Copies items from D3 files to Windows directories
- Copies files from Windows directories to D3 files
- Automatically converts attribute marks to Windows end-of-line markers (CRLF) when copying to Windows
- Converts Windows CRLF markers to attribute marks when copying from Windows to D3

This handles the data format conversion needed for proper file transfer between the two systems.

instruction: What options are available with the wincopy command?
input:
Command: wincopy
Parameters: filename - Specifies the name of the D3 file or a Windows directory path, item.list - Specifies a list of items to copy, * - Specifies that all items in the file or directory path should be copied
Options: L - Specifies lowercase item names on destination, U - Specifies uppercase item names on destination, O - Specifies overwrite existing items on destination.
output:
The wincopy command has the following parameters and options:

Parameters:
- filename: Specifies the D3 file name or Windows directory path
- item.list: Specifies a list of items to copy
- *: Copies all items in the file or directory path

Options:
- L: Specifies lowercase item names on destination
- U: Specifies uppercase item names on destination  
- O: Specifies overwrite existing items on destination

These options give you control over naming conventions and whether to overwrite existing files during the copy operation.

instruction: Give me examples of using wincopy to transfer files between D3 and Windows
input:

Examples: 
Example 1: wincopy myfile a b c to:(c:\temp - copies the items a, b, and c from the D3 file myfile to the Windows directory c:\temp as files a, b, and c as long as files a, b, and c do not already exist.
Example 2: wincopy myfile a b c (uo to:(c:\temp - copies items a, b, and c from the D3 file myfile to the Windows c:\temp directory as files A, B, and C, overwriting any existing file.
output:

Example 1: Basic copy without overwrite
wincopy myfile a b c
to:(c:\temp

This copies items a, b, and c from the D3 file 'myfile' to the Windows directory c:\temp as files a, b, and c, but only if those files don't already exist.

Example 2: Copy with uppercase names and overwrite
wincopy myfile a b c (uo
to:(c:\temp

This copies items a, b, and c from the D3 file 'myfile' to the Windows c:\temp directory as files A, B, and C (uppercase), overwriting any existing files.

The (uo options specify: u = uppercase names, o = overwrite existing files.

instruction: How can I check which user accounts are currently logged on to specific ports?

- who: Shows information for the current port
- who {port.number}: Shows information for a specific port
- who {*}: Shows account names for all logged-on ports
- who {user-ID}: Shows information for a specific user-ID

The command displays the relationship between port numbers, user-IDs, and account names, helping you see who is currently logged on and where.

instruction: What output format options does the who command support?
input:
Command: who
Options: a - Converts output format to D3 format, showing the user-ID followed by the account name. This is the default setting. c - Converts output format to R83 format. n - No pause option suppresses the pause at the end of the page on the terminal. z - Displays status of all ports, including those not logged on. The account name displays as 'unknown' for ports not logged on.
Examples: who 56 ref bob | who (a [1321] D3 output for WHO display specified. | who 56 bob ref
output:
The who command supports several output format options:

- a: D3 format (default) - shows user-ID followed by account name
- c: R83 format - converts output to R83 compatibility format
- n: No pause - suppresses page-end pauses on the terminal
- z: Shows all ports including those not logged on (displays 'unknown' for unoccupied ports)

Examples:
- who: Shows current port (e.g., "56 ref bob")
- who (a: Explicitly uses D3 format
- who (c: Uses R83 format (e.g., "56 bob ref")

The default D3 format shows user-ID first, then account name, while R83 format reverses this order.

output:

instruction: How do I exit the monitor debugger?
input:
Command: q
Syntax: q{!}
Description: The q command quits the monitor debugger.
Parameters: ! - Optional parameter that bypasses the normal D3 termination and terminates the process abruptly. CAUTION: This form should be used only in extreme situations where even quitting from the monitor debugger aborts.
Example: The user is prompted: 'Leaving the Monitor debugger terminates the D3 process.' To confirm, type 'y' (without pressing ENTER).
output:
Use the q command to quit the monitor debugger.

Syntax: q{!}

Normal exit:
- Type q to quit normally
- You'll be prompted: "Leaving the Monitor debugger terminates the D3 process."
- Type 'y' (without pressing ENTER) to confirm termination

Forced exit:
- Use q! to bypass normal D3 termination and terminate abruptly
- CAUTION: Only use q! in extreme situations where normal quitting fails

The normal q command provides a safety prompt since exiting the monitor debugger terminates the entire D3 process.
